headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify these forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
And for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our oth
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other Executive Vice Presidents, Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski and Chad Utermark. The entire executive management team would like to thank everyone on our Nucor, Harris Steel, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, NuMit Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for a job extremely well done in 2014. You worked hard, worked smart, worked together and, most importantly, worked safely to deliver solid improvements in our performance despite steel industry conditions that remained very challenging.
I am pleased to report that full year of 2014 net income increased significantly by 46% to $714 million. We also achieved a very robust growth in our cash generated from operations. 2014's operating cash flow represents our strongest performance since 2008, demonstrating the strength of our business model. Best of all, our more than 23,000 teammates continued their excellent work implementing our company's strategy for profitable growth. Subsequent to the last cyclical peak in the steel industry, Nucor has invested significant capital in a large number of projects that improve our cost structure and expand our product portfolios to include more value-added, higher-margin offerings. In 2014, we began to see some of the early benefits from these strategic investments. There are more to come. In 2015, these investments will enhance our ability to navigate through the current challenges presented by energy industry turbulence and high levels of imported steel.
I will now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to review Nucor's fourth quarter performance and financial position. Following Jim's comments, I will update you on current market conditions and execution of our strategy for long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Fourth quarter of 2014 earnings of $0.65 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.50 to $0.55 per diluted share. This outperformance was largely driven by better-than-expected results from our sheet mills, joist and deck business
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Fourth quarter of 2014 earnings of $0.65 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.50 to $0.55 per diluted share. This outperformance was largely driven by better-than-expected results from our sheet mills, joist and deck business and our direct reduced iron plant in Trinidad. Newly acquired Nucor Steel Gallatin made solid contributions to our fourth quarter earnings and cash flow, even after absorbing about $9 million or $0.02 per diluted share after tax purchase accounting expenses early in the quarter. We are encouraged by our fourth quarter performance given the strong seasonal and other influences dampening volumes during the period. Total sales tons to outside customers declined 10.5% in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter. Our strong full year 2014 earnings improvement highlights the value of Nucor's industry-leading product diversity. We are North America's only manufacturer of all 4 major steel mill products: bars, beams, plate and sheet. Our steel mill shipments of 22 million tons increased more than 6% year-over-year, which is more than double the U.S. steel industry's overall growth rate. The increased steel mill volume was further leveraged by steel mill metal margin expansion of $32 per ton. That's a $37 per ton gain, and our average steel sales price outpaced a $5 per ton increase in our average cost of iron units consumed.
In addition to the strong profit growth at our core Steelmaking Operations, Nucor's downstream steel product segment more than doubled its profitability in 2014. These businesses are benefiting from the initial stages of recovery in nonresidential construction markets. Particularly strong volume growth was achieved in our joist, decking and rebar fabrication products.
Nucor's 2014 earnings improvement was achieved despite a significant operating loss at our new DRI facility in Louisiana. Nucor Steel Louisiana's 2014 operating loss totaled $135 million or $0.28 per diluted share after tax and $35 million or $0.07 per diluted share after tax for the fourth quarter.
Production operations at the Louisiana facility have remained suspended since the process gas heater experienced a failure in early November. Due to the lead times on the specialty steel pipes that must be replaced, we estimate that the plant will not resume operations until late in the first quarter. The process gas heater is not part of the DRI technology utilized by Louisiana, but it is ancillary equipment required to operate the plant. The DRI technology itself has worked well and established new world-class quality levels, as measured by metallization rates and carbon content. Although Louisiana has been a challenging start-up, it will be a major step forward in the implementation of our long-term raw materials strategy. The recent declines in iron ore pricing and the fourth quarter profits generated by our DRI facility in Trinidad provide further validation to our work over the past decade establishing and growing Nucor's DRI production capacity.
A quick comment about our tax rates, which can be confusing due to the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. After adjusting our profits belonging to our business partners, the effective tax rate was 33.6% for the fourth quarter and 35.3% for the full year of 2014. Nucor's financial position remains strong at the end of 2014. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 37%. Cash and short-term investments totaled more than $1.1 billion at the close of 2014, putting our net debt-to-capital ratio at approximately 31%. Our next significant debt liquidity is not until December of 2017. Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until August of 2018. Nucor is the only North American steel producer to hold an investment-grade credit rating.
John mentioned our very robust operating cash flow generation in 2014. Cash provided by operations of approximately $1.3 billion comfortably exceeded capital spending of $668 million combined with cash dividends paid to our shareholders of $475 million.
In 2014, Nucor's strong balance sheet, liquidity and cash flow again allowed us to take advantage of attractive opportunities to build long-term earnings power. During the fourth quarter, we completed our purchase of all of the equity of Gallatin Steel for a cash purchase price of approximately $779 million. The acquisition was funded from cash on hand and the issuance of approximately $300 million of commercial paper. By the end of 2014, we have reduced the acquisition-related commercial paper outstanding by half, to about $151 million. For 2015, we estimate capital spending will be approximately $500 million. Most of our recent larger-scale projects have been completed or are nearing completion. Our capital spending forecast also reflects our joint decision with Encana, our natural gas working interest partner, to extend our drilling suspension through the end of 2015. This year's capital spending for drilling will be very modest and consists of drilling a few wells required to maintain leasehold rights. Depreciation and amortization for 2015 is expected to total about $700 million.
Nucor's financial strength, as evidenced by our strong balance sheet and healthy cash flow generation through the economic cycle, is the bedrock foundation to our mission of growing shareholder value. From this position of strength, we are able to allocate our shareholders' valuable capital to the most optimal or attractive usage at any given point in time. Our financial strength allows us to invest in capital projects during severe industry downturns, when the long-term returns are most attractive. It allows us to make strategic acquisitions when the right assets at the right price become available in the marketplace. And just as importantly, it allows us to reward our shareholders with a steadily growing base dividend, supplemental dividends during up-cycles and opportunistic share repurchases.
During the current downturn from 2009 through 2014, our investments totaled nearly $6 billion, with about 2/3 going to capital spending and 1/3 going to acquisitions. These diverse projects are growing Nucor's long-term earnings power by expanding our product portfolios into higher value-added offerings that are less vulnerable to imports, by improving our cost structure and, finally, by building upon our market leadership positions. Growing stronger during downturns is a long tradition of Nucor. It is how we achieve higher highs in profitability from one cyclical beat to the next.
With our disciplined approach to capital allocation and success in building long-term earnings power, Nucor is able to reward shareholders with attractive cash returns. Our base dividend has more than tripled since the end of 2007. With the increase effective with next month's quarterly dividend payment, Nucor has increased its base dividend every year since it first began paying dividends in 1973, or 42 consecutive years. During the last industry up-cycle from 2004 to 2008, Nucor paid a total of $5 per share in supplemental dividends. And over the 10-year period ending in 2014, Nucor returned a total of $6.7 billion of capital to our shareholders through dividends and opportunistic stock buybacks.
The Nucor team's unrelenting focus remains on continuing to build upon our record of being effective stewards of our shareholders' valuable capital.
First quarter of 2015 earnings will be impacted by the significant headwinds that developed for the steel industry at the end of 2014. The collapse in oil prices has triggered inventory reductions amongst pipe and tube producers, an important customer group for Nucor and the overall steel industry. At the same time, imports are up dramatically entering 2015. Now on the positive side, we continue to see favorable trends in non-residential construction markets that will benefit both our steel mills and fabricated construction products.
Overall, we expect first quarter 2015 earnings will decrease from the fourth quarter to a level slightly exceeding the first quarter of 2014. Nucor will again follow our practice of providing quantitative guidance in the final month of the quarter.
Whatever short-term economic and steel industry conditions we face in 2015, Nucor's unrivaled position of strength will allow our team to continue to execute on our proven strategies for delivering profitable long-term growth. We appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. There certainly has been an abrupt change in the near-term outlook in recent weeks. The 2 headwinds mentioned by Jim, collapsing oil prices and surging imports, will certainly challenge our team during the first quarter. But that's okay. Our
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. There certainly has been an abrupt change in the near-term outlook in recent weeks. The 2 headwinds mentioned by Jim, collapsing oil prices and surging imports, will certainly challenge our team during the first quarter. But that's okay. Our team has faced and overcome challenges and adversity in the past, and we will do it again.
Energy is an extremely important driver of demand for steel in the U.S. and here at Nucor. Pipe and tube producers serving the energy markets represent approximately 10% of our steel mill shipments. Meaningful production and inventory adjustments by our pipe and tube customers are currently underway. Following this period of marketplace adjustment, we believe the future remains very positive for low-cost energy production in North America. Importantly, lower energy costs, over time, should support increased U.S. manufacturing activity and consumer spending. That is all very positive for Nucor.
The other major headwind is from a renewed surge in import activity. Full year 2014 imports of finished carbon steel products are estimated to have jumped to an unreasonable and unacceptable level of approximately 34 million tons. That's an increase of about 37% over 2013 and just under 2006's record level of 35 million tons. Indications are that January 2015 finished steel imports may set a monthly record of around 3.9 million tons. These short-term headwinds are significant, and Nucor is extremely well positioned to navigate through them and we will.
Some key advantages of our company come immediately to mind. We will benefit from our low and highly variable cost structure. Additionally, we expect continued growth in nonresidential construction activities. Iron units are our largest-single cost item. As previously mentioned, profitability at our DRI plant in Trinidad is benefiting from the large declines in iron ore costs. After resuming production, the Louisiana facility will also benefit from what appears to be an oversupplied ore market over at least the next several years.
Continuing on the raw material cost topic, we believe that the U.S. scrap is currently significantly overpriced versus iron ore and global scrap markets. Based on increased import steel penetration, slack international demand for U.S. scrap, the strength of the U.S. dollar and moderating U.S. demand for scrap, we expect scrap prices to fall dramatically in early 2015. During this period of transition, Nucor will continue to utilize our unmatched global supply chain to optimize our raw material costs. Our investment in DRI and in scrap yards as well as our access to international raw material markets gives Nucor best-in-class capabilities and flexibility in approaching the market for iron units.
Nonresidential construction markets account for more than half of the end-use demand for Nucor's products. As measured by square footage, U.S. nonresidential construction activity increased by 6.7% in 2014. We expect continued improvement in 2015. It is worth noting that the 2014 square footage activity level represents only about 56% of 2007's peak activity level. So there's plenty of room for additional improvement.
Whenever the steel industry and the economy hit unexpected periods of turbulence, like what we are experiencing now in early 2015, Nucor will do what Nucor always does. We will grow bigger, stronger and more profitable, and we will outperform our competitors.
Here are the reasons why Nucor will do this. Our balance sheet, and recycled cash flow generation, is unrivaled by any of our competitors. Our industry-leading product and market diversity continues to grow as we move up the value chain in all of our businesses. The recent expansions in our offerings include normalized and heat-treated plates, wider and lighter sheet steels, additional SBQ and wire rod products and new piling sections. All of these products are less impacted by irrationally priced imports. Our low-cost structure will benefit from increased DRI production capacity, as our new Louisiana facility completes its start-up process this year.
Our commitment to achieving commercial excellence by leveraging Nucor's competitive advantages, such as product diversity and operational flexibility, to create more value for and build stronger relationships with each of our customers. And most importantly, Nucor's employees, the right people. They are our company's greatest asset and our greatest competitive advantage.
Here are just a few of the 2014 achievements implementing our strategy of investing for long-term profitable growth. In the fourth quarter, our Nucor-Yamato structural steel mill began prime production of its new sheet piling sections. The initial output was sold to Skyline Steel, our piling distributor, and will be installed next month at a construction project in New Jersey. Nucor-Yamato expanded its product portfolio to include wider piling sections that are lighter and stronger, covering more area at a lower installed cost. The market for these high value-added niche products is currently largely supplied by imports. In addition to taking advantage of Nucor-Yamato's world-class structural steel manufacturing capabilities, our customers will benefit from this new domestic solution, which will create valuable synergies with the other products and services offered by Skyline Steel. Acquired in 2012, Skyline is the market leader in its business, with an unrivaled package of engineering support, stocking locations, processing centers and dedicated sales teams.
In 2014, Nucor Steel Hertford County plate mill leveraged its heat treating capabilities to capture a growing share of the market for value-added plate products. For example, in 2014, Hertford County has more than doubled its share of the bridge market during the current steel industry downturn. Over the same period, shipments to higher-margin OEM customers have doubled as a percent of the mills' total volume. These value-added products are also less vulnerable to pressure from commodity imports.
Our Nucor Steel Berkeley sheet mill's successful start-up in 2014 of its wide-light capital project continued to build momentum. Shipments of the new wide-light products totaled over 120,000 tons in the first year. Berkeley now has the lightest hot-roll gauge capacity -- capability of any sheet mill in the Southern U.S. market, and with a finished product width of up to 72 inches.
We estimate the size of the new market segment now available to Berkeley to be approximately 4 million tons annually. Of particular importance, the upgrade allows Nucor to produce thinner, high-strength steel grades that could be used to develop lightweight automotive applications.
In closing, based upon all of this strategic factors and the faith, the absolute faith I have in our team's ability to face and overcome challenges, I remain very confident that Nucor's best years are still ahead of us.
Thank you for your interest in Nucor. We would now be happy to take your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Luke Folta with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Luke Folta with Jefferies.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on -- in the release, you talked about what you're expecting in terms of demand in the first quarter and you made some comments around expectation for significantly lower scrap prices. I'm just trying to get a sense -- if you could give
componenttext: First question is on -- in the release, you talked about what you're expecting in terms of demand in the first quarter and you made some comments around expectation for significantly lower scrap prices. I'm just trying to get a sense -- if you could give us some more color around what your price expectations are heading into 1Q. What's baked into the assumption that earnings should be slightly higher year-on-year? And also could you give us some sense of what your LIFO expectation would be as well, that would be helpful.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the first part of the question, and then I'll turn it over to Jim for the LIFO comments. Let me start by saying that our first quarter outlook is based upon what we see today in the current scrap prices. As I mentioned in the script, the
componenttext: Let me start with the first part of the question, and then I'll turn it over to Jim for the LIFO comments. Let me start by saying that our first quarter outlook is based upon what we see today in the current scrap prices. As I mentioned in the script, there's numerous reasons why we believe that, that pricing will decline dramatically in the early part of the year, we believe probably in the first quarter. One of the biggest drivers to that is when you look at our scrap pricing -- excuse me, our steel pricing, our steel pricing has already gone down and decreased across products maybe $50 to $100 a ton. As a result, scrap pricing has to follow that steel pricing down. We see the pricing -- steel pricing under pressure because of the imports that are coming in that's produced with iron ore and giving them a cost advantage today over our scrap market. That has to and we believe will adjust. There's several other reasons we believe that we're going to see scrap pricing drop significantly over the next couple of months. You've got the strength of the U.S. dollar. Global scrap markets are low. Scrap imports are bound to start coming in. And as I mentioned, decreased demand for steel scrap as a result of decreased production of steel because of the pressure that we're seeing, both because of the imports being produced by the iron ore and because of the iron -- the oil pricing, as we mentioned in the script. So given these reasons, we believe very strongly that we will see a dramatic drop in scrap pricing in the first quarter. The other thing I would want to mention is that we are seeing some impact from the lag of the scrap pricing moves in the inventories in our mill. So we have currently in our mills higher-priced scrap because there's usually a 4- to 6-week lead time in -- lag time in our ancillary inventories. So given all of those reasons, we believe that a, scrap pricing is going to come down dramatically. And I want to stress that it's following steel pricing now. If steel pricing has already come down, scrap pricing must follow. And I also want to mention that, again, that we based our first quarter outlook based upon current scrap pricing. Jim, do you want to touch upon the LIFO adjustments?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Luke, we're assuming a $25 million LIFO credit for the year. And obviously, if the prices fall as dramatically as we think they could, we'll end up having a larger credit as the year advances. But we're going to start the year out looking at -- I thi
componenttext: Yes. Luke, we're assuming a $25 million LIFO credit for the year. And obviously, if the prices fall as dramatically as we think they could, we'll end up having a larger credit as the year advances. But we're going to start the year out looking at -- I think it comes to $6.5 million expense in the first quarter for a $25 million annualized base.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just to be clear, whatever big scrap move that we could see in February -- I think last update, some of the people we were talking to were looking for a down 30 to 50. Maybe that's changed over the past week or so. But your expectation now would
componenttext: Okay. So just to be clear, whatever big scrap move that we could see in February -- I think last update, some of the people we were talking to were looking for a down 30 to 50. Maybe that's changed over the past week or so. But your expectation now would be -- your guidance was based on today's scrap price before a big down move in February? Or would that be included in that? Just...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Luke, as John was explaining, we tend to have scrap on the ground. And so when we made the forecast, we were assuming that the benefits of the foreign scrap price, we don't know if it's going to fully come through in February or partly leak into Marc
componenttext: Yes. Luke, as John was explaining, we tend to have scrap on the ground. And so when we made the forecast, we were assuming that the benefits of the foreign scrap price, we don't know if it's going to fully come through in February or partly leak into March, that we'll just start to see some of the benefit in March. And so if we see it sooner, our results could be a better. But our forecast probably is a bit conservative in terms of receiving any benefit from scrap prices, if that helps. We don't like to give a specific "here's the number" because, quite frankly, we don't have that. It's a bottoms-up forecast with every business unit individually making their -- a forecast.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then just the second one, in terms of your energy demand, your shipments, John, I think you said it was 10% or so of your total steel shipments. Can you give us some sense of how that breaks out by product, flat-rolled versus S
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just the second one, in terms of your energy demand, your shipments, John, I think you said it was 10% or so of your total steel shipments. Can you give us some sense of how that breaks out by product, flat-rolled versus SBQ? And anything in terms of the magnitude of how that's changed in just sort of the past month or so or in the first quarter would be very, very helpful.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: The vast majority of it is horizontal sheet products, probably about 3/4 of the -- of our shipments come out of sheet products, maybe 75%, 80%. Now there's a small amount that comes out of SBQ. As I mentioned, we've seen a significant adjustment by our cu
componenttext: The vast majority of it is horizontal sheet products, probably about 3/4 of the -- of our shipments come out of sheet products, maybe 75%, 80%. Now there's a small amount that comes out of SBQ. As I mentioned, we've seen a significant adjustment by our customers who produce pipe and tube that goes into the oil business. They're adjusting their inventories, and we're seeing that impact on our -- upon our order book. But I do want to stress, as I mentioned several times in the script, the investments that we've made over the last several years in diversifying our products and our markets will help us get through this period. Just as one tidbit of information, when you look at just in 2014, there's about 700,000 tons of product that is either new or value-added products or product that we can now supply into markets that we could not supply into previous to these investments. So although we're going to be taking a hit on the oil and gas, no doubt about it, 10% of our shipments go into that, we believe that through the investments that we've made in diversifying our products, we'll mitigate that input effect. I will also stress, as I mentioned in the script, that 50% of our products go into nonresidential construction. We expect to see continued improvement in that market.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Matt Murphy with Union Bank of Switzerland.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Matt Murphy with Union Bank of Switzerland.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question just on, I guess, your order book. I mean, how do you -- what sense are you getting? Are customers holding off, waiting for the market to find the bottom? Or are you finding pretty healthy inquiries out there?
componenttext: A question just on, I guess, your order book. I mean, how do you -- what sense are you getting? Are customers holding off, waiting for the market to find the bottom? Or are you finding pretty healthy inquiries out there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Other than -- again, other than the pipe and tube, that's oil and gas related, the rest of the markets are okay. Now certainly, there's a lot of doubt about what's going to happen, both on pricing, but I think more particularly on what the customers view
componenttext: Other than -- again, other than the pipe and tube, that's oil and gas related, the rest of the markets are okay. Now certainly, there's a lot of doubt about what's going to happen, both on pricing, but I think more particularly on what the customers view might happen with scrap pricing, which is why I'm once again emphasizing that it's an unusual event, where we're going to be seeing scrap pricing following steel pricing down. Typically, it's reversed. This time, because of the pressure from imports and from our competition that is ore based, we are seeing the inverse effect take place. Steel pricing has gone down before scrap pricing. We believe that scrap -- as I mentioned, scrap pricing will follow it down, and it will happen pretty quickly and pretty dramatically. But again, it's following the steel pricing down, not the other way around. And I think our customers understand that. And so they're not expecting large price decreases as scrap continues to move down because we've already seen the impact of that on our pricing. One other -- a bit important that I mention in terms of just bookings as a general statement, we talk about imports being high and although we've been successful in some of our trade cases on rebar and hot-rolled coil and wire rod, there's still a lot of that import steel that's in inventory that is impacting our order book, and we'll see that in the next couple of months.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's helpful. And then when you talk about repeatedly your strategy of going into higher-end product, I guess, how are you finding competition from imports in the higher-end categories? And if that remains a better business for Nucor than for impo
componenttext: Sure. That's helpful. And then when you talk about repeatedly your strategy of going into higher-end product, I guess, how are you finding competition from imports in the higher-end categories? And if that remains a better business for Nucor than for imports, is it fair to say maybe we would see imports continuing to attack in some of the lower-end applications? So maybe you don't get the volume growth, but you still get the margin growth from the higher-end products. Maybe if you could just talk through how that might look.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, the higher-value products have a greater resistivity to imports as well as having higher margins. So you kind of get a double benefit of that. In terms of your comment about would we expect to see volumes not growing, I would not agree with
componenttext: Well, clearly, the higher-value products have a greater resistivity to imports as well as having higher margins. So you kind of get a double benefit of that. In terms of your comment about would we expect to see volumes not growing, I would not agree with that statement. We expect to see our volumes grow in the higher value-added products. Because as we continue to develop them, we gain more and more market share. And as has always been Nucor's policy, we don't give up on the low commodity products, okay? We're in this game across the full spectrum. We're just as interested in maintaining our market share in rebar as we are in developing the advanced high-strength steels. We'll grow in all of the products that are out there. We will not concede market share easily to either our competitors or to our imports -- to an imported price. We will continue to fight. In other words, we'll gain higher ground without giving up what we already have. Does that answer your question?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Perfect.
componenttext: Perfect.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question for you. I'm guessing, John, that you're probably following this Leveling the Playing Field Act that Senator Brown introduced today -- last December. And I was just wondering if you can kind of walk us through what that might actually me
componenttext: I have a question for you. I'm guessing, John, that you're probably following this Leveling the Playing Field Act that Senator Brown introduced today -- last December. And I was just wondering if you can kind of walk us through what that might actually mean for the steel industry. How could that benefit Nucor? And this might be asking too much, but your kind of handicap on whether essential legislation might be able to make it through a Republican Congress?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to ask our political guru, here Pat McFadden, to answer that question to the level that we can answer it.
componenttext: Well, I'm going to ask our political guru, here Pat McFadden, to answer that question to the level that we can answer it.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That legislation, it's going to be good for us. But it's something that's very difficult to get through the system. So I really don't want to go into it on this call, but I'd be happy to talk to you afterwards.
componenttext: That legislation, it's going to be good for us. But it's something that's very difficult to get through the system. So I really don't want to go into it on this call, but I'd be happy to talk to you afterwards.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Give us -- maybe call after the -- give us a call later in the day or tomorrow, and we'll give you some more color on that.
componenttext: Give us -- maybe call after the -- give us a call later in the day or tomorrow, and we'll give you some more color on that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I will definitely follow up. And maybe just asking on the -- I'll just ask about the trade case on "flat-rolled products." Where does that stand right now? I know it's hung up a little bit because of the concerns about the injury determination. Wit
componenttext: Great. I will definitely follow up. And maybe just asking on the -- I'll just ask about the trade case on "flat-rolled products." Where does that stand right now? I know it's hung up a little bit because of the concerns about the injury determination. With pricing rolling over as much as it has over the past quarter, are we getting a little bit closer to the point where we may actually see something pretty soon?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to answer that specifically. I will say that -- I'll make a general statement that we will be proactive and we will be aggressive. The level of imports, as I mentioned, have reached absolutely ridiculous levels. And we believe that there's a
componenttext: I'm not going to answer that specifically. I will say that -- I'll make a general statement that we will be proactive and we will be aggressive. The level of imports, as I mentioned, have reached absolutely ridiculous levels. And we believe that there's a potential for action coming up. We're monitoring the situation very closely, and we'll be aggressive. When we look back at the last couple of cases and the success that we've had over those cases -- we had the rebar case against Mexico. We were very successful in that case. And we saw rebar imports from Mexico reduced by about 70%. We've seen wire rod, the case against China, result in virtually eliminating the Chinese wire rod from the U.S. market. And then finally, I would mention the suspension agreement, the elimination and suspension agreement for hot-rolled coil in -- against Russia. And we've seen significant -- we anticipate continuing to see significant reductions in Russian hot-rolled coil coming into the country. So based upon those recent successes, we feel pretty good about our chances going forward. I'm going to leave it at that. We'll monitor it closely. We'll be aggressive. And we'll be proactive in pursuing cases when it's appropriate.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Sohail Tharani with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Sohail Tharani with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, on the end markets, more than 50% is non-res, 10% energy. Anything big you want to mention after these 2?
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, on the end markets, more than 50% is non-res, 10% energy. Anything big you want to mention after these 2?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mentioned, as we've mentioned several times on past calls, automotive. We're looking at about 10% of our automotive-qualified steels go in today -- 10% of our steels that are qualified go into automotive. We're shipping into that sector. If you look at
componenttext: I mentioned, as we've mentioned several times on past calls, automotive. We're looking at about 10% of our automotive-qualified steels go in today -- 10% of our steels that are qualified go into automotive. We're shipping into that sector. If you look at our total tonnage, about 5% of that will be going into automotive today. Obviously, we don't normally count structural steel beams, not much of that can go into the automotive. So we don't factor that in. But if you look at what is possible to go into automotive, we're shipping about 10% of that flat-rolled, SBQ into automotive today. SBQ is just about -- I think we picked up a little bit in SBQ over the last year. It might have bumped up to about 11%. But again, flat steel represents the vast majority of the products that we're putting into automotive.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And you postponed the drilling this year. How long can you do that? Is that part of the contract that if gas prices remain low, you have ability to continue postponing it?
componenttext: Got you. And you postponed the drilling this year. How long can you do that? Is that part of the contract that if gas prices remain low, you have ability to continue postponing it?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We can continue to postpone it as long as we and our partner, Encana, agreed to do that. And as we've said -- mentioned several times, we have a great relationship with them and we constantly communicate with them. We made a decision this year to suspend
componenttext: We can continue to postpone it as long as we and our partner, Encana, agreed to do that. And as we've said -- mentioned several times, we have a great relationship with them and we constantly communicate with them. We made a decision this year to suspend drilling other than the few wells that are necessary to maintain the leaseholds. And we'll take a look at the situation again during the course of the year. If we should see a sudden increase, sporadical increase in pricing, we'll begin drilling. If we don't, we will suspend again. The key thing to remember about this agreement is the gas is in the ground. It's not evaporating. It's not going anywhere. It's there waiting for the right, the optimum opportunity for us to take it out of the ground.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are you hedged for gas this year?
componenttext: Are you hedged for gas this year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are partially hedged for gas. It's a percentage of our production at the Louisiana plant because we're using that, obviously, at our steel mills that are operating.
componenttext: We are partially hedged for gas. It's a percentage of our production at the Louisiana plant because we're using that, obviously, at our steel mills that are operating.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Brian Yu with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Brian Yu with Citi.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to the comment you made earlier about the scrap prices. And as I think about it, I guess, first, if I may start with the scrap yards. And I was wondering if you could share with us what's happening with the buy prices that you're getting
componenttext: I want to go back to the comment you made earlier about the scrap prices. And as I think about it, I guess, first, if I may start with the scrap yards. And I was wondering if you could share with us what's happening with the buy prices that you're getting at the yards you operate? I mean, are -- how much are those down, say, as you go into February?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to give specific numbers, but I will say that they are down. They're down significantly. And we expected that, and we're reacting properly to it. But I'm not going to give any -- obviously, any specific numbers. Our competitors would love to
componenttext: I'm not going to give specific numbers, but I will say that they are down. They're down significantly. And we expected that, and we're reacting properly to it. But I'm not going to give any -- obviously, any specific numbers. Our competitors would love to hear that number.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the energy side, obviously, that's having an impact. Can you give us a sense of how much of orders dropped so far in the year versus, say, what you were seeing back in 4Q? And is there any backlogs when you ship to the OCTG manufacturers that you
componenttext: Okay. On the energy side, obviously, that's having an impact. Can you give us a sense of how much of orders dropped so far in the year versus, say, what you were seeing back in 4Q? And is there any backlogs when you ship to the OCTG manufacturers that you're working off of now?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a small backlog that we're working our way through. We're working with our customers. We understand the situation that they face and the inventory problems that they're looking at. So we've been working with them on that. As I've said before,
componenttext: Yes, there's a small backlog that we're working our way through. We're working with our customers. We understand the situation that they face and the inventory problems that they're looking at. So we've been working with them on that. As I've said before, we've seen significant drop in the orders of flat-rolled product going into oil and gas. Our other markets remain very strong. Heavy truck is still looking very good. Automotive is still looking very good. So there are areas where we feel confident that our order book remains strong, but we have seen a significant drop in our orders for  specifically pipe and tube that goes into the energy markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can I get one more in? Gallatin, I think, roughly half of their shipment is going to the energy markets. Are there other end markets that, that facility...
componenttext: Okay. Can I get one more in? Gallatin, I think, roughly half of their shipment is going to the energy markets. Are there other end markets that, that facility...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I apologize, but I've got to correct you right off the bat. It's true that about half of their product goes into pipe and tube, but the vast majority of that goes into structural tubing. Only about 10% of Gallatin's product shipments go into energy-relate
componenttext: I apologize, but I've got to correct you right off the bat. It's true that about half of their product goes into pipe and tube, but the vast majority of that goes into structural tubing. Only about 10% of Gallatin's product shipments go into energy-related pipe and tube, which is similar to our number here on the call.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just let you know -- ask you about there's some talk about blast furnaces' idling capacity in response to the level of import and the destocking on energy tubular, as you mentioned. So 2 questions, I guess. One is how long do you think this de
componenttext: I wanted to just let you know -- ask you about there's some talk about blast furnaces' idling capacity in response to the level of import and the destocking on energy tubular, as you mentioned. So 2 questions, I guess. One is how long do you think this destocking might last? And secondly, would Nucor be among those that's preemptively idling some capacity in response to large level of imports?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard to predict how long this is going to last. That's somewhat of a function of how long and how deep the oil pricing situation goes on. You hear all kinds of predictions on that. Frankly, as far as I'm concerned, it's anyone's guess at this p
componenttext: Well, it's hard to predict how long this is going to last. That's somewhat of a function of how long and how deep the oil pricing situation goes on. You hear all kinds of predictions on that. Frankly, as far as I'm concerned, it's anyone's guess at this point. It's entirely up to the producers and how much oil they start pumping out of the ground. But currently, if we were to remain at today's levels of oil pricing and we look at the inventories, we would be looking at probably around 6 to 7, 8 months of inventory on the ground at today's usage. Now having said that, there's always a shock to a system when something has a radical change, and we see that happening today. Big change, people throughout the entire supply chain are caught with inventory on hand with some radical -- some major change, major reduction in the orders. Given that, there will be a period of time when all of this kind of works out, starts flushing through, and we'll begin to see the orders for pipe and tube going into energy returning to a new normal level. Albeit less than where it was, but that will be some level greater than where it is today but less than where it was a year ago. The other thing that I would mention about that is that -- you asked about shutting or reducing our capacity. As you know, Timna, our furnaces are extremely flexible. We make that decision on a weekly basis. We want our mills to fill orders. And given our variable cost structure and the flexible schedules that we have, we can react extremely quickly to any changes, okay? Whether or not we see some improvement in that energy market quicker than we anticipated or whether we see an uptick in one of our other markets, we stand ready to be very quick in responding to any changes in the market. Again, when you compare our operation to those of a blast furnace, clearly, once you shut down a blast furnace, it's down for a while. And we have much greater flexibility. We don't need to shut down an EAF; we can simply skip a couple of heats or skip a couple of shifts and come back in a couple of days if we see the order book warranting it.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. If I could, I just want to see if you could give a little bit more color on the plate and SBQ markets, given that they have some energy exposure. I just haven't heard as much about them lately.
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. If I could, I just want to see if you could give a little bit more color on the plate and SBQ markets, given that they have some energy exposure. I just haven't heard as much about them lately.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen that much of an impact on either the plate or the SBQ markets. Now certainly, there are some small amount. But a lot of our plate that goes into what we would call energy might go into wind towers and other applications that really aren't
componenttext: We haven't seen that much of an impact on either the plate or the SBQ markets. Now certainly, there are some small amount. But a lot of our plate that goes into what we would call energy might go into wind towers and other applications that really aren't impacted just heavily by the oil price going down. As I mentioned earlier, SBQ does sell a little bit into that. It's been growing. We've been focused on that as a growth area, but it's not that heavy for us. Where we see the bigger impact, frankly, on our order book in both SBQ and particularly in plate is due to the imports, [indiscernible] imports. So we see some impacts due to the oil prices, but frankly a larger impact due to imports. Timna, one more thing that I might mention because you've mentioned specifically about the plate market, when you think about some of the infrastructure, although it's coming way too slowly, there are some infrastructure repairs being made, particularly in the bridge. And there's couple of bridges going on, some bridge fabrication, bridge repair. And our plate business is doing well in that arena. So we've seen some pickup in our plate order book as we've sold to general infrastructure and particularly bridge fabrication.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question just about this whole change in the raw material markets here, particularly with the scrap move and the lack of the scrap move, I guess, relative to iron ore in the past 6 months. But when you look forward, I would think the next few mon
componenttext: I have a question just about this whole change in the raw material markets here, particularly with the scrap move and the lack of the scrap move, I guess, relative to iron ore in the past 6 months. But when you look forward, I would think the next few months would be a great opportunity for you to gain share, particularly on the sheet market, not to close down your production because you're going to -- if you're not already, you're going to become the low-cost producer in the market for sheet. And when you look at the sheet market, it's about 2/3 iron ore or integrated based; about 1/3, you and the rest of mini mills on sheet side. And you've been suffering from a relative cost disadvantage because scrap didn't come down relative to iron ore in the last 6 months, and now it is. So I guess, my question is going forward, you've kind of seen the worst scenario, you relative to integrated like AKS and AK, but isn't there a great opportunity to pick up some share as your cost drop and their cost basically don't?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll say that we have seen the worst of the times relative to our position because we do believe scrap is coming down. I will point out that we've fared a little bit better on our cost side relative to most of our EAF-based competitors because of ou
componenttext: Well, I'll say that we have seen the worst of the times relative to our position because we do believe scrap is coming down. I will point out that we've fared a little bit better on our cost side relative to most of our EAF-based competitors because of our DRI situation. Recall that with the iron ore pricing going down, our DRI cost of production has been going down also. So we've seen a benefit at our Trinidad facility, and we will see a benefit as our Louisiana facility comes back into line. So yes, we believe we've seen the worst of the times, okay? Yes, we see scrap pricing going down, and we will benefit from that. Yes, we've had it better than our other competitors in the EAF arena because of our DRI capabilities. I'm not going to comment on just what all of that means going forward. We will stay competitive. We will take care of our customer needs. We will continue to supply our customers with high-quality, fairly priced product on time with great service. And we'll see how it plays out in the marketplace.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Andrew Lane with Morningstar.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Andrew Lane with Morningstar.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given the significant declines in both iron ore and natural gas prices since this time last year, do you expect to achieve profitable DRI production in Louisiana shortly after the facility is restarted? Or will it likely take some time to ramp up producti
componenttext: Given the significant declines in both iron ore and natural gas prices since this time last year, do you expect to achieve profitable DRI production in Louisiana shortly after the facility is restarted? Or will it likely take some time to ramp up production before your output is profitable?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it will take some time to ramp up our production, and it will also take some time to work through the high-end and higher-cost iron ore inventory that we have on the ground, iron ore that was purchased last year that we have not worked our way throu
componenttext: Well, it will take some time to ramp up our production, and it will also take some time to work through the high-end and higher-cost iron ore inventory that we have on the ground, iron ore that was purchased last year that we have not worked our way through because the facility has been out of commission. So it will take time to work through that inventory. It will take some time to get up to full production. But we expect to see the Louisiana facility running well and profitable by the end of the year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then to change gears, you mentioned that the energy end market represents about 10% of your steel mill shipments. Could you provide a split as to how much of that total is directly associated with the shipments for oil and gas drilling pr
componenttext: Okay, great. And then to change gears, you mentioned that the energy end market represents about 10% of your steel mill shipments. Could you provide a split as to how much of that total is directly associated with the shipments for oil and gas drilling projects and how much is associated with shipments for other energy-related applications, such as power generation?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't break it down that definitively. I would say to you that probably -- if you look at the energy pipe and tube as opposed to other oil and gas applications, you're looking at probably 90% going directly into the energy pipe and tube that woul
componenttext: Well, we don't break it down that definitively. I would say to you that probably -- if you look at the energy pipe and tube as opposed to other oil and gas applications, you're looking at probably 90% going directly into the energy pipe and tube that would be associated with drilling, maybe 10%, I'm giving you rough numbers here, maybe 80-20, 90-10, somewhere in that area.

componenttext: Okay, okay. That's helpful. If I can ask one last question. Would you be able to provide an update as to how the integration process is going for the Gallatin Steel operations? And are the incremental 2015 benefits you initially expected still intact?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would love to do that actually, okay? The integration is going extremely well. We expected that it would go well. The team there is a great team. Their management style, their culture is very similar to our Nucor culture. So we anticipated a smooth inte
componenttext: I would love to do that actually, okay? The integration is going extremely well. We expected that it would go well. The team there is a great team. Their management style, their culture is very similar to our Nucor culture. So we anticipated a smooth integration. But I have to tell you what, it's gotten even better than we anticipated. Those guys are doing a great job. The financial team there, I'd give a call out to them. They very, very quickly integrated to our financial programs. I'm surrounded by some financial people in the room, and they're all nodding their heads, saying what a great job the Gallatin financial team did in getting up to speed, very quickly converting the systems, integrating the systems. I would also make that statement relative to the commercial team. They integrated extremely well into our commercial team. We're enjoying the synergies that we anticipated from that. And hey, it's going great.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and welcome to the Nucor Corporation First Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that
componenttext:
Good day, everyone and welcome to the Nucor Corporation First Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy.
More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, and our other Executiv
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, and our other Executive Vice Presidents, Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, [indiscernible] and Chad Utermark. The entire executive management team would like to thank everyone on our Nucor Harris Steel, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, NuMit, Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for working hard, working smart, working together, and most importantly, working safely to take care of our customers in the first quarter of 2015.
The term steel industry challenges are significant, but whether it's a short-term challenge such as energy and industry turbulence or a structural challenge such as excess global steel capacity, the Nucor team always runs toward the challenge, not away from it. We address the challenges we face head on. Times of adversity allow us to demonstrate the strength of Nucor's business model. With our unrivaled competitive advantages and adaptability, Nucor grows stronger during periods of industry distress. Achieving that goal is the unrelenting focus of the more than 23,000 Nucor teammates each day as they continue their excellent work, implementing our company strategy of long-term, profitable growth.
I will now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to review Nucor's first quarter performance and financial position. Following Jim's comments, I will update you on current market conditions and execution of our strategy for long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. First quarter of 2015 earnings of $0.21 per diluted share compared favorably against fourth quarter of 2014 earnings of $0.65 per diluted share and year ago first quarter earnings of $0.35 per diluted share. The profitability of our steel mi
componenttext:
Thanks, John. First quarter of 2015 earnings of $0.21 per diluted share compared favorably against fourth quarter of 2014 earnings of $0.65 per diluted share and year ago first quarter earnings of $0.35 per diluted share. The profitability of our steel mills segment for the first quarter of 2015 declined approximately 46% compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. An unprecedented level of imports flooding the domestic market in late '14 and early 2015 has pressured steel selling prices margin volumes for all of our steel mill products. The hot roll sheet market is the weakest as the result of the combined impact of surging imports and severe inventory correction underway in the energy, pipe and tube sector. Capacity utilization of the steelmaking operations fell to 65% in the first quarter of 2015 from the fourth quarter's rate of 76%. Not surprisingly, our sheet mills experience the largest decline quarter-over-quarter in production and shipments. And Nucor Sheet Mill shipments decreased 14% over this period, which compared to an 8% decline in total steel mill shipments. Steel mill profitability was also impacted by continued erosion in selling prices that outpaced decreases in raw material price -- costs. The decline in steel selling prices exceeded the reduction in our scrap usage cards, which were $39 per ton quarter-over-quarter. Average sales prices dropped $70 per ton for plate, $67 [ph] per ton for beams and $49 per ton for sheet. The first quarter 2015 performance of our raw materials segment includes an operating loss of approximately $44 million or $0.09 per diluted share in our new facility in Louisiana. That is larger than the approximately $35 million operating loss Nucor Steel Louisiana experienced in the fourth quarter. Our Louisiana team has completed repairs and adjustments to the processed gas feeder that failed in November of last year. Operations resumed during the last week of the first quarter.
On the positive side, our downstream products segment continues to capitalize on the slow but steady growth underway in nonresidential construction markets. As expected, the segment's first quarter profitability decreased from the fourth quarter level due to typical seasonal factors. However, compared with the year ago quarter, segment pretax profitability increased to more than $32 million from less than $2 million. Particularly strong profit improvement was achieved in our joist and decking and metal building systems businesses.
Quick comments about our tax rate, which can be confusing, due to the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. After adjusting our profits that belong to our business partners, the effective tax rate was 33.9% for the first quarter. Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 36% at the closing of the first quarter.
Cash and short-term investments totaled $1.3 billion, including our net debt to capital ratio at approximately 28%. Our net significant debt maturities is not until December 2017.
Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes a $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until August of 19 -- of 2018. Nucor Steel in North American steel producer to hold the investment-grade credit rating.
Nucor continues to generate very robust operating cash flow throughout the cyclical up and downs that characterize the steel business, but our highly variable cost structure will benefit from significant reductions in working capital during downturns. That was the case again in the first quarter of 2015, with cash provided by operations of $564 million, a dramatic increase from the year-ago first quarter. Our strong cash flow allows us to increase our liquidity and retire the year-end 2014 commercial paper balance of about $150 million that had been issued to fund a portion of the Gallatin Steel acquisition in the fourth quarter of last year.
First quarter of 2015 capital expenditures totaled $70 million. We continue to estimate full year 2015 capital spending will be approximately $500 million. Most of our recent largest scale gross projects have been completed or are nearing completion.
Depreciation and amortization for 2015 is expected to total about $700 million.
John made an excellent point about the strength of Nucor's business model. It is one that enjoys competitive advantages and a degree of flexibility that cannot be matched by any of our competitors in the North American steel industry. Nucor's strong balance sheet, consistently healthy cash flow generation and conservative financial practices are critical components of our business model. Times of adversity such as what our industry is currently undergoing, once again, highlight the strengthening value of Nucor's significant competitive advantages and superior adaptability. Our focus is not on survival but on growing stronger.
Earnings in the second quarter of 2015 are expected to be somewhat improved from the first quarter. The second quarter should be followed by further improvement in the second half of 2015, given the ongoing strength of nonresidential construction and its impact on our steel mills and downstream businesses. Nonresidential construction activity accounts for more than half of the end-use demand for our products. Margin in the steel mills segment are expected to improve, although we are -- we will not realize the full benefits of lower raw material costs until there is greater stability in steel pricing. As service centers stocking runs its course during this transition period, steel prices are expected to stabilize and to rebound. Second quarter performance at raw material segments will reflect continued high losses at the Louisiana-derived facility and the impact of a nearly completed 1-month maintenance outage at our facility in Trinidad. Our Louisiana plant resumed production will be assuming higher cost iron ore that was on hand when the plant suspended operations following a failure in its process gas in early November. Our steel products segment is expected to achieve continued improvement in profitability during the second quarter. All 3 major fabricated construction products, joist and decking, fabricated rebar and mill buildings are experiencing significant year-over-year gains in bookings, backlogs and backlog margins. Over the past several months, our confidence has increased that the overall U.S. nonresidential construction market is set to deliver square footage growth in the range of at least 7% to 8% in 2015. Such a growth rate would still place the market almost 40% below the peak level of 2007.
Whatever short-term economic and steel industry conditions we face for the remainder of 2015, Nucor's unrivaled position of strength will allow our team to continue to execute on our proven strategies for delivering profitable, long-term growth and shareholder returns. We appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Nucor's culture has always been defined our willingness to tackle and overcome challenges. We don't ignore problems. That's not an effective strategy for success or even survival. When confronted by challenges, we find ways to grow stronger,
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Nucor's culture has always been defined our willingness to tackle and overcome challenges. We don't ignore problems. That's not an effective strategy for success or even survival. When confronted by challenges, we find ways to grow stronger, while fixing or mitigating the problem. During the first quarter, unprecedented volumes of steel entrants continued to be a major challenge for industry. Joists and government support of their steel industries has resulted in a neglect of global steel production. A brazen disregard for international trade rules has led to the dumping of steel products in our market. As a result, 1:3 tons of steel sold in the U.S. today is produced abroad by a less efficient, less safe and less environmentally friendly countries. This is a real crisis for our industry. We are tackling this issue head-on through fighting back. Nucor's working on a bipartisan basis with Members of Congress and with the administration to ensure that we have a strong and effective tools to combat unfair trade. If Congress passes trade promotion authority legislation authorizing the president to enter into new free trade agreements, we believe the bill must be balanced with the strongest possible trade enforcement mechanisms so that steel and other industries have the tools we need to fight this blatant disregard for international trade rules. There is substantial part from both Democrat and Republicans for doing this. Additionally, the administration must take a much tougher line with countries that break the law. We have a set of rules governing trade. We follow those rules. When foreign countries and producers break those rules, there must be meaningful consequences. Applying tariffs and other remedies is simply holding governments accountable for the agreements that they sign. To that end, Nucor continues to assess market conditions and will be proactive and aggressive in pursuing trade cases when and where it is appropriate.
I will now update you on some of our team's organic growth initiatives underway to improve our long-term course position and expand our product portfolios to include more value-added, higher-margin offerings that are less impacted by the tsunami of imports. After restarting operations at the end of the first quarter, Nucor Steel Louisiana is once again producing DRI at world-class quality levels that our team established prior to the equipment failure. It's important to note that the process is not part of the DRI technology utilized by Louisiana, but it is ancillary industrial equipment required to operate plant. During the Louisiana just-completed shutdown, modifications to the process gas heater's original design were implemented to prevent the recurrence of a similar failure. One significant bearing modification was the insulation of 2 large dampeners to enable the process gas heater to control of cooling rate which will expand the life of the tubes that have failed in the past. Another significant modification was the addition of nitrogen to the outlet of the heater to significantly reduce and any collateral damage in the event of any future failure. Louisiana has been a challenging plant. Nevertheless, it is a major step forward in the implementation of our long-term strategy to optimize our iron use process. In fact, we believe that it has already provided short-term benefits. The presence of our leading DRI facility, having produced 1.3 million [ph] tons one year and preparing to resume production at the end of last quarter, was a meaningful factor supporting February's dramatic adjustment of more than $100 per ton in scrap prices. With that very much support, I believe in the long-term benefit of our DRI investment.
In the first quarter of 2015, our [indiscernible] County North Carolina plate mills recently added heat treating and normalizing assets, continued to run at full capacity of approximately 245,000 tons annually. The Hertford County team is capturing a growing share of value-added and higher-margin plate products. Relative to an investment of approximately $150 million, our value-added capabilities are for incremental, pretax profit that should average $200 per ton with the cycle.
During the first quarter, the first field installation of Nucor models new wider, sections, was successfully completed. This new product is the result of a $115 million project we started up in the fourth quarter of last year. Our customers will benefit from this new domestic solution as they pursue by-American, government-funded infrastructure projects.
Nucor-Yamato expanded product portfolio will also create valuable synergies with the other products and services by the Skyline Steel piling distribution business we acquired in 2012. Our goal over the next several years is to grow our wider timing sections annual volume to 100,000 tons, which combined steel mill and distribution pretax profit potential of approximately $450 per ton.
Momentum continues to build at Nucor Steel Berkeley's $98 million, wide capital project. That started off in early 2004 and has shipped approximately 120,000 tons last year. We expect to ship  about 200,000 tons of the new products in 2015 and eventually grow volume to be at least 300,000 tons annually, with pretax profit averaging $100 per ton through the cycle. Berkeley now has the lightest, hot capability of hot sheet metal in the southern United States market. And with a finished capability of up to 72 inches. Of particular importance, the upgrade allows new quarter produce higher strength skin steel grades at the plant used to develop lightweight automotive applications.
As I've said earlier, these are just some of the growth initiatives. I look forward to updating you again next quarter on our progress implementing our strategy for profitable growth.
Here are some of the reasons why we believe Nucor will continue to deliver profitable, long-term growth and industry-leading returns on capital. Our loan and highly variable core structure is Nucor's bedrock competitive advantage. We understand that to generate attractive returns in a commodity business, you have to be a low-cost producer and seek continual improvement in your core structure. Our balance sheet strength and through the cycle cash flow generation all depends on long-term focus and ability to take advantage of profitable growth opportunities, particularly the cyclical downturns. Our upstream, vertical integration, and raw materials enhances the profitability and flexibility of Nucor's core steelmaking business. The David J. Joseph Company's unmatched global raw material supply chain, combined with our investments in DRI and scrap yards is Nucor's best-in-class capability and flexibility in optimizing what is by far among our largest single cost item, iron units.
Our industry-leading product and market diversity continues to grow as we move up the value chain in all of our businesses. Our downstream vertical integration and the to value-added steel products enhances the products' profitability and flexibility of Nucor's core steelmaking business. Our expanded channels to market, such as Harris Steel, Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel increase our ability to compete with unfairly traded imports by expanding our opportunities to add value to our customers. Our commitment to achieving commercial excellence by leveraging Nucor's competitive advantages such as product diversity and operational flexibility to create more value for, and build stronger relationships with, each of our customers. And most importantly, Nucor's employees. The right people. They embraced the Nucor culture's pay-for-performance philosophy and passion for continuous improvement in taking care of our customers, our shareholders and their fellow teammates. That is why they're our company's greatest asset and our greatest competitive advantage. As it stands true throughout Nucor's history, our company's best years are ahead of us. Thank you for your interest in Nucor. We would now be happy to take your questions.
