componenttext: So if we focus on one particular, let's just take structural, the reason is basically the same for all categories. At the beginning of 2014, we're looking at the situation where, as you said, imports were much lower. Service center inventories were down. We were going into a year where nonresidential construction was projected to be up. Frankly, in the first quarter, we were talking about price increases that were out there. So a combination on all of those resulted in much higher outage rates within the first quarter last year compared to the first quarter of this year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if you look at the full year expectation, Jim, I think you said square footage, you expected to grow about 7% to 8% this year. Would you -- I mean, outside the first quarter issue, as it pertains to destocking in imports, would you expect t
componenttext: Okay. And then if you look at the full year expectation, Jim, I think you said square footage, you expected to grow about 7% to 8% this year. Would you -- I mean, outside the first quarter issue, as it pertains to destocking in imports, would you expect that these categories should grow about in line with that pace?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again taking imports out of the equation, if we see the growth that were projecting in nonresidential construction, we should see volume increases compared to the first quarter, particularly as we move out of the seasonal issues that are affecting the fir
componenttext: Again taking imports out of the equation, if we see the growth that were projecting in nonresidential construction, we should see volume increases compared to the first quarter, particularly as we move out of the seasonal issues that are affecting the first quarter in a lot of our businesses. Particularly, when you look at some of the downstream businesses such as Harris, where frankly it's hard to do a lot of construction work in the first quarter, January and February, and many of our Harris facilities are located in Canada, just to kind of amplify the situation. So we do expect it to improve as we come out of the first quarter. Weather conditions improve. And we see the expected increase in nonresidential construction.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just secondly on DRI, understanding that you've got high cost inventory to work through that impacts costs and the outages well. If we -- imagine a scenario where we stay in the sort of 2 60, [ph] 2 75 pig iron environment and iron ores $50, can you g
componenttext: And just secondly on DRI, understanding that you've got high cost inventory to work through that impacts costs and the outages well. If we -- imagine a scenario where we stay in the sort of 2 60, [ph] 2 75 pig iron environment and iron ores $50, can you give us some sense of how we should think about profitability of DRI at full production? Is it profitable meaningfully at that level?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would be cash positive at those levels. When you're talking about pig iron at 2 50. We do transfer DRI on the pricing mechanism that's based upon pig iron. And I would say that a level of about 2 50 for pig iron, we are cash positive. I would also poin
componenttext: It would be cash positive at those levels. When you're talking about pig iron at 2 50. We do transfer DRI on the pricing mechanism that's based upon pig iron. And I would say that a level of about 2 50 for pig iron, we are cash positive. I would also point out that they'll be quick to point out that I personally believe 2 50 for pig iron is unsustainable level. It's the result of some significant unusual currency issues and the geopolitical issues. So I personally would not expect that to stay at that level long term. Having said all of that, we've said from the beginning when we talked about the DRI project, that over the course of the cycles, there's going to be times when we get singles, times when we bunt and times when we have grand slams. We talked and just last quarter about the positive contribution from our Trinidad operation, when pig iron is at a more normalized rate. And we expect it to be back up to those levels again, and we expect to see very good returns on our DRI investment when that occurs.

componenttextpreview: Certainly, we can do that. As always, these things come, and there's many, many factors. But the key one, the driver for all of this was frankly the steel performance, the performance of our steel mill. We've -- we -- in forecasting, we underestimated the
componenttext: Certainly, we can do that. As always, these things come, and there's many, many factors. But the key one, the driver for all of this was frankly the steel performance, the performance of our steel mill. We've -- we -- in forecasting, we underestimated the impact that we would have on our margins of scrap pricing going down. We got through the lower scrap price quicker. And frankly, in some of our products, we had higher volumes. So the combination of an improved margin relative to our forecast and some volume increases above our forecast, we did beat the forecast, as you mentioned.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay, so it to questions of finish up then, out next follow-up of that is, one, why did prices fall less than sheet than they did in plate and beams? It's Very high profile to see how much she prices that followed but plate and beams I thought that just fall and more recently with $100 scrap move in February. So why did you see plates and beams fall more than you did for sheet in the quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, one element that you have to take into account when you -- to answer that question is some portion of our sheet business is in a quarter-over-quarter contract pricing that's based on some mechanism. So when you -- there's a lag time before you see t
componenttext: Well, one element that you have to take into account when you -- to answer that question is some portion of our sheet business is in a quarter-over-quarter contract pricing that's based on some mechanism. So when you -- there's a lag time before you see that decrease in those contract pricing. I would also point out that, although the import situation is very serious on sheet product, particularly plate, there's just been on believable tsunami of imports -- imported plate over the last 2 quarters. And that, of course, had a dramatic impact on our pricing of the plate.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And the other thing I want to ask but maybe philosophical. Now I've just been surprised at how -- I know prices always overcorrect in a down market, but why would a company like a mini mill like yourselves, you have the flexibility r
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And the other thing I want to ask but maybe philosophical. Now I've just been surprised at how -- I know prices always overcorrect in a down market, but why would a company like a mini mill like yourselves, you have the flexibility ramp continue to produce at these very low prices to match imports? Is in their price where you say, "No, I don't want to make that low a margin, and I'm going to hold out and it's" The prices are expected to recover. Why's everybody, including yourselves I guess, continue to produce and offer these low-priced tons at import levels at the important equivalent levels? What do you think?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's always a balance, right? Want to look at your -- the lawyer put through your facility, which obviously impacts your fixed costs of that facility. So that's one issue. Secondly, we need to take care of our customers. We don't give up market shar
componenttext: Well, it's always a balance, right? Want to look at your -- the lawyer put through your facility, which obviously impacts your fixed costs of that facility. So that's one issue. Secondly, we need to take care of our customers. We don't give up market share. Sometimes, when you lose a customer or lose a business opportunity, it's hard to regain it. And we -- our customers count on us being there even when it's in a difficult pricing environment. So those are couple of reasons.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to operate. I'll also point out that, and let enough that an answer that question, if I didn't whatever you we wanted to hear on that. But given the radical change in the scrap costs, which we frankly believe were coming because of the large g
componenttext: We continue to operate. I'll also point out that, and let enough that an answer that question, if I didn't whatever you we wanted to hear on that. But given the radical change in the scrap costs, which we frankly believe were coming because of the large gap between scrap price and iron units, we felt that we could work our way through those tough times, keep our customers satisfied, maintain our market share, not lose good opportunities, knowing that we would ultimately be able to, as a result of scrap costs going down, be able to correct, our pricing and get it closer to the market -- that import price and maintain the margin.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on trade. So it seems like you're taking kind of a two-pronged or maybe the industry's taking a two-pronged approach to trade issues. One is just putting together a trade case keep hearing about on flat rolled. But the other is on the
componenttext: My first question is on trade. So it seems like you're taking kind of a two-pronged or maybe the industry's taking a two-pronged approach to trade issues. One is just putting together a trade case keep hearing about on flat rolled. But the other is on the legislative front. Senator Brown has got these leveling the playing field rules that is -- assumed trying to Attachment B at this point. It seems like maybe there's a chance to get to some of these rules that actually change the way that the harm is measured in the U.S. through in the next few months here. How do those 2 things impact one or the other? So my question is, would you wait to file a trade case on flat rolls if you think you can maybe change the rules at the ITC on the harm decision? Or are those completely independent?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: When we fight, we use both fists, okay? so those are a two-pronged approach, and we're going to use both prongs to achieve a level playing field so that our teammates can be successful, which we know they will be in on a level playing field. I mentioned t
componenttext: When we fight, we use both fists, okay? so those are a two-pronged approach, and we're going to use both prongs to achieve a level playing field so that our teammates can be successful, which we know they will be in on a level playing field. I mentioned the last couple of calls that I felt we're gaining traction in Washington both of those fronts. I still do. We are getting a much better reception. People are beginning to understand. I believe people are beginning to understand the impact of these illegally traded products on our industry and on our teammates and steelworkers in general. It's about focusing and pursuing trade cases when it's appropriate and moving forward on the legislative front at the same time. We see great opportunity, frankly, on the legislative front, particularly with the TPA discussions that are going on today. We are pushing very, very hard and getting good reception on both sides of the aisle to the concept that if TPA is going to be approved, it must be approved with strong trade language to protect our industries and give us the ability to better and more effectively and more proactively fight illegally traded products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just maybe on the trade case. What is kind of your outlook there on timing? It seems like it's been a pretty weak first quarter for most folks at this point. And second quarter probably for most folks are also clearly difficult. Do you thi
componenttext: Great. And then just maybe on the trade case. What is kind of your outlook there on timing? It seems like it's been a pretty weak first quarter for most folks at this point. And second quarter probably for most folks are also clearly difficult. Do you think the case is ready to bring at this point? Or do you think need to demonstrate more harm before the industry's comfortable filing?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me be clear. We will continue to assess the market, and we will implement the trade case at the appropriate time.
componenttext: Well, let me be clear. We will continue to assess the market, and we will implement the trade case at the appropriate time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just one last one quickly on scrap. What's your view for the upcoming month? It seems like flows are decided to pick up a little bit, which would be negative, and maybe demand is coming back. Where do you think it all shakes out?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just one last one quickly on scrap. What's your view for the upcoming month? It seems like flows are decided to pick up a little bit, which would be negative, and maybe demand is coming back. Where do you think it all shakes out?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly, our forecast would be pretty flat line for the rest of the year. Obviously, when you talk about scrap, there's always slightly -- slight variations in different regions. We expect some movements in different regions, up 5, down 10, so forth
componenttext: Well, frankly, our forecast would be pretty flat line for the rest of the year. Obviously, when you talk about scrap, there's always slightly -- slight variations in different regions. We expect some movements in different regions, up 5, down 10, so forth, as we go throughout the year. But overall, as you look at the year as a whole, I think we're going to be pretty flat line on scrap pricing.

componenttext: Well, as we've mentioned in the script, this is a quarter of transition. So we're not quite sure when we'll see that actual kick in. Today, there's, I would say, a very modest improvement in lead times, very modest, frankly not significantly over first quarter. And that would expand -- that will go across probably [indiscernible] basically all of our products. Now the one exception I would add to that is in the sheet side on the galvanizing cobalt products. Those lead times are longer, and we still see a pretty strong demand in that area.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: All right. So kind of following up to that, and on your volume expectations, gradual construction and order demand improvements. componenttext: I'd say it's a combination of the 2. And again, to kind of give you help further than that, be more specific than that, very difficult to do. So I would say it's a combination of both.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And is that -- and I guess I'm just wondering what the recovery profile of that basically be watching imports coming off to drive that back up?
componenttext: Yes, okay. And is that -- and I guess I'm just wondering what the recovery profile of that basically be watching imports coming off to drive that back up?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, there will be a number of factors. Imports beginning to drop-off, although we have seen them, I want to stress that it's going to be a while before we see the drop-off. Although we've seen a slight decline in licenses, there was so much out t
componenttext: Well, again, there will be a number of factors. Imports beginning to drop-off, although we have seen them, I want to stress that it's going to be a while before we see the drop-off. Although we've seen a slight decline in licenses, there was so much out there in the pipeline that this is going to take off. And so much is already reached the service centers and just build up their inventories, is going to be a while before we work our way through that. Now I can tell you that for the first time, this month, the numbers that just came out on service center inventories, we see them being down just a little bit. But imports are something that we should certainly watch, and there are other factors, too, particularly our sheet business, when you want to look at oil price. And I can't tell you when it's going to recover, but certainly, we see the tremendous impact on our flat roll business as a result of oil pricing going from $100 to $50 of irons are way down. Same situation there. We flooded the pipeline with material. There's been a complete stop as they work their way through this inventory at some point. I frankly don't think it will be in the second quarter, but some point during the course of the year, maybe third or fourth quarter. We'll start working our way through that inventory. And we see order rate that are consistent with the new normal drilling levels that are expected with the lower price.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Another thing you can keep your eye on is currency. Obviously, the strong dollar has an impact on what's happening both in our raw material side and on our steel shipment side as it relates to imports and other factors. So I tried to give a couple of thin
componenttext: Another thing you can keep your eye on is currency. Obviously, the strong dollar has an impact on what's happening both in our raw material side and on our steel shipment side as it relates to imports and other factors. So I tried to give a couple of things that you can keep an eye on, but there's a multitude of things that we have to watch to see what's going to happen as we go forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good color. I'm basically just sort of looking like at this is a like 3-month thing or a 6-month thing is excellent thing, but I understand it's dependent on all those factors. I guess, on scrap prices, I've been a little bit surprised that
componenttext: Yes, that's a good color. I'm basically just sort of looking like at this is a like 3-month thing or a 6-month thing is excellent thing, but I understand it's dependent on all those factors. I guess, on scrap prices, I've been a little bit surprised that no one is expecting, it seems, much more weakness there, given we've seen a continued iron ore weakness. So I guess, just on scrap, what's the confidence that we've got some pricing stability for a while here?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, all I can tell you my confidence level. We gave you our projections. We believe in that projection. We think that's going to be fairly stable. Right now, iron ore pricing, it fluctuates a little bit, but it's been relatively stable also. If there's
componenttext: Well, all I can tell you my confidence level. We gave you our projections. We believe in that projection. We think that's going to be fairly stable. Right now, iron ore pricing, it fluctuates a little bit, but it's been relatively stable also. If there's been a dramatic change in iron ore pricing, it might have a reflection on scrap pricing, but we just -- we don't see that at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question. If you're assuming that scrap prices are going to stay relatively flat the rest of the year, and you saw some massive $100 drop a couple of months ago. When do you -- or are you now picking up share against the integrated mills who are
componenttext: I have a question. If you're assuming that scrap prices are going to stay relatively flat the rest of the year, and you saw some massive $100 drop a couple of months ago. When do you -- or are you now picking up share against the integrated mills who are basically fixed cost? And when you get the $100 drop in scrap, they sell very little of it.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes. Obviously, it's made us much more competitive. And the reason people buy steel is based upon 4 things: service, quality, on-time delivery and price. When we were in a situation where there was such a difference between scrap and iron ore pricing,
componenttext: So yes. Obviously, it's made us much more competitive. And the reason people buy steel is based upon 4 things: service, quality, on-time delivery and price. When we were in a situation where there was such a difference between scrap and iron ore pricing, where we're at a real disadvantage on pricing [indiscernible] and that impacted our competitive position. Frankly, when I think about how we did during the period where the gap is so large, really proud of the job our team did on the other 3 elements of quality, service and delivery. That has kept us in the game when we had $100 differential on cost. Now that that is to reduce, but it's scrap coming down, very confident that we will continue to be aggressive and now we've got -- the competitive on all 4 of those elements, and I feel good about the way to go forward in terms of getting market share.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is your sense that you're gaining market share now?
componenttext: Is your sense that you're gaining market share now?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to get into specifics at any one my point in time. I'll just say again, we don't have the pricing competitive, with not only integrated, but we reduced the gap between important pricing and off-pricing. And we can't -- we delivered superior
componenttext: I'm not going to get into specifics at any one my point in time. I'll just say again, we don't have the pricing competitive, with not only integrated, but we reduced the gap between important pricing and off-pricing. And we can't -- we delivered superior quality, service and delivery. Based on all of that, I'm confident that our team will gain market share as we move forward throughout the year. Now this could be a lot of practice that come into that as we talked about in the past.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on Tim's commentary on there. I guess, I'm equally surprised that spot price didn't [indiscernible] down, I guess, below $4.50. I know imports continue to be a big problem. But if you just look at where import offers are today ver
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on Tim's commentary on there. I guess, I'm equally surprised that spot price didn't [indiscernible] down, I guess, below $4.50. I know imports continue to be a big problem. But if you just look at where import offers are today versus physical flows and the like, do you think you've past the point where now it's more about domestic competition for market share versus all the domestic producers trying to keep out of the imports?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me be real clear about this. Import continues to be our #1 threat. We're focusing on pricing here. You need to remember is that there is such a tremendous overcapacity. We're looking at 300 million tons of excess capacity worldwide. That is going to c
componenttext: Let me be real clear about this. Import continues to be our #1 threat. We're focusing on pricing here. You need to remember is that there is such a tremendous overcapacity. We're looking at 300 million tons of excess capacity worldwide. That is going to continuously put pressure on our market and our profitability. Now having said that, we have -- we have reduced the gap between domestic pricing an imported pricing. But look, imports are going to continue to be our #1 challenge for our industry and our company as a whole.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Second question is -- and this is more with your iron ore pellets inventory. Yes, how much inventory do you typically do you keep on hand at Louisiana? And I think you mentioned earlier that [indiscernible] the high-cost in the second quarter. So if that occurs...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me -- if I may just correct that because I want to make sure we're clear on this. Today, there's a gap of about $60 between the pricing of the iron ore that we have on the ground and what market pricing would be. At the end of the second quarter, we e
componenttext: Let me -- if I may just correct that because I want to make sure we're clear on this. Today, there's a gap of about $60 between the pricing of the iron ore that we have on the ground and what market pricing would be. At the end of the second quarter, we expect that we will reduce that gap from about $60 down to about $15. We'll reduce the gap by $45 at the end of the second quarter. It will be -- it will take us through the third quarter sometime around the middle or towards the end of the third quarter before we reduce that last $15 gap and get us down to market price for iron ore. Please continue with your question, but I want to correct that -- be very specific on that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. That was a lot more information that I would hope for. So great. But maybe along those lines, tell me how much inventory do you typically keep on hand, so they're [indiscernible] prices will move down in Q1? How long before that actually flows
componenttext: All right. That was a lot more information that I would hope for. So great. componenttextpreview: Well, we talked about the growth -- the organic growth that we've had and the products that we bring to market. So certainly we would expect to see market share growth in our structural business before new product sections. And we talked about the growth
componenttext: Well, we talked about the growth -- the organic growth that we've had and the products that we bring to market. So certainly we would expect to see market share growth in our structural business before new product sections. And we talked about the growth in the sheet side of the business with Pipelife project and expect that to grow year-over-year. As for [indiscernible] we continue to put the products onto the marketplace with continuous -- we are continually moving forward with our projects in SBQ that will -- I expect market share growth in that area also. And so -- what did I leave out? Play?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We mention number when I heat treat and normalizing running basically full capacity. And I mentioned the projects that we're doing in our bar mills [indiscernible] believe our raw products which we are introducing a rod products in the market and have bee
componenttext: We mention number when I heat treat and normalizing running basically full capacity. And I mentioned the projects that we're doing in our bar mills [indiscernible] believe our raw products which we are introducing a rod products in the market and have been accepted there was some expect to grow our market share there also. And as I mentioned on calls in the past, one of the few bright spots in the marketplace today is automotive. And we expect to grow our participation in automotive this year also. Last year, we shipped about maybe 1.1 million tons of sheet in SBQ combined products into automotive. And this year, we're anticipating shipping about 1.45 million tons of combined sheet and SBQ into the automotive market. And part of that is being supported by -- I'm going to put a little plug in here for our new Detroit automotive office that we've just established. And it's been well received by the automotive companies. We have metallurgical and engineering teammates and sales people in that office to help support our push into automotive.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's useful, John. Are there any updates on the sort of order Body and White industries since last we spoke about this?
componenttext: That's useful, John. Are there any updates on the sort of order Body and White industries since last we spoke about this?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, body and white that's one of our strong points that we're moving into. And when you say exposed, exposed accounts or about 15% of the weight of steel per vehicle. And certainly, we want to play in that game. And we do, we have a product of the
componenttext: Certainly, body and white that's one of our strong points that we're moving into. And when you say exposed, exposed accounts or about 15% of the weight of steel per vehicle. And certainly, we want to play in that game. And we do, we have a product of the component of that and have put into that exposed application. But it's clearly not a focus point for us. And we look at body and white, we see 75% of the volume going in there. But that's our focus point. We look at typical closures, which represents 25%, the remaining 25%, and only 10% of -- 15% of that is exposed. So combined, you're looking at 15% out of the total weight of the car. It's not something -- that's not where our major push is going to be.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. So my final one is just on the DRI project and raw materials, so I totally understand, the raw material strategy here. And we do like the fact that there is this additional flexibility built into your sort of iron units procu
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. So my final one is just on the DRI project and raw materials, so I totally understand, the raw material strategy here. And we do like the fact that there is this additional flexibility built into your sort of iron units procurement here. But I mean, can we consider a scenario where the pricing environment is just not conducive to DRI being profitable? And let's assume it's something with iron ore and pig iron spreads? Could you talk a little bit about what sort of flexibility you have in your raw material contracts to effectively flex those volumes down and, say, reduce DRI up or just -- because it isn't profitable or can't be profitable and perhaps bring it back again later in the future when margins are spreads are a bit more conducive to that plant being profitable?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We get our raw material, our iron ore, from 4 different sources. And I'm going to give you the specifics of what kind of contracts we have with each one of those particular  suppliers. But in general, we have a level of about 25% to 35% flexibility in the
componenttext: We get our raw material, our iron ore, from 4 different sources. And I'm going to give you the specifics of what kind of contracts we have with each one of those particular  suppliers. But in general, we have a level of about 25% to 35% flexibility in the supply of raw material iron unit. So we can cut it back 25% to 35%, and I'm talking now, of course, all the contracts. I'm not going to get anymore specific than that. But if I may, I want to take a moment here because it was a question earlier about the DRI and how should they look at when the cost of iron units are going down -- when we would see an improvement. And I answered the question because it was tied originally back to the amount of weeks on hand of iron ore supply inventory we had. And I said that we keep about 5 to 6 weeks of inventory on the ground. That is an accurate statement. But if he was looking to get some sense of when pricing changes relative to iron ore pricing on an index basis changes, we need to factor in the issue that we buy on a quarterly basis with a lag -- lagging quarter. So whoever asked that question earlier about seeing changes in the pricing of our raw material going into Louisiana, please bear in mind when you see the change occur in the index, there is a one quarter lag in the pricing that we see at the plant itself. Okay?

componenttext: Okay. Let me work through this. No, this is, in fact, a planned preventative maintenance program shutdown that is scheduled in advance and must be done on a regular, annual basis. Without getting into all the technical jargon, you need to shut down and clean out the piping in the furnace. It's done about once a year. It takes about a month. It's a normal process. Now we are frankly adding a piece of equipment in Trinidad that has nothing to do with the Louisiana situation. It's a polisher. What we called polisher, to improve the yields is the product ships from Trinidad to the United States. But that's a side issue. There's no failure in Trinidad and anticipate its value. It is strictly a planned maintenance outage. In terms of what we expected to hit us with, Jim, do you have that number?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and welcome to the Nucor Corporation First Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that
componenttext:
Good day, everyone and welcome to the Nucor Corporation First Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy.
More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, and our other Executiv
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, and our other Executive Vice Presidents, Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski and Chad Utermark. The entire executive management team would like to thank everyone on our Nucor Harris Steel, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, NuMit, Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for working hard, working smart, working together, and most importantly, working safely to take care of our customers in the first quarter of 2015.
The turn steel industry challenges are significant, but whether it's a short-term challenge such as energy and industry turbulence or a structural challenge such as excess global steel capacity, the Nucor team always runs toward the challenge, not away from it. We address the challenges we face head on. Times of adversity allow us to demonstrate the strength of Nucor's business model. With our unrivaled competitive advantages and adaptability, Nucor grows stronger during periods of industry distress. Achieving that goal is the unrelenting focus of the more than 23,000 Nucor teammates each day as they continue their excellent work, implementing our company strategy of long-term, profitable growth.
I will now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to review Nucor's first quarter performance and financial position. Following Jim's comments, I will update you on current market conditions and execution of our strategy for long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. First quarter of 2015 earnings of $0.21 per diluted share compared favorably against fourth quarter of 2014 earnings of $0.65 per diluted share and year ago first quarter earnings of $0.35 per diluted share. The profitability of our steel mi
componenttext:
Thanks, John. First quarter of 2015 earnings of $0.21 per diluted share compared favorably against fourth quarter of 2014 earnings of $0.65 per diluted share and year ago first quarter earnings of $0.35 per diluted share. The profitability of our steel mills segment for the first quarter of 2015 declined approximately 46% compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. An unprecedented level of imports flooding the domestic market in late '14 and early 2015 has pressured steel selling prices, margins and volumes for all of our steel mill products. The hot roll sheet market is the weakest as a result of the combined impact of surging imports and the severe inventory correction underway in the energy, pipe and tube sector. Capacity utilization at our steelmaking operations fell to 65% in the first quarter of 2015 from the fourth quarter's rate of 76%. Not surprisingly, our sheet mills experienced the largest decline quarter-over-quarter in production and shipments. Nucor Sheet Mill shipments decreased 14% over this period, which compared to an 8% decline in total steel mill shipments. Steel mill profitability was also impacted by continued erosion in selling prices that outpaced decreases in raw material price -- costs. A decline in steel selling prices exceeded the reduction in our composite scrap and scrap usage costs, which were $39 per ton quarter-over-quarter. Average sales prices dropped $70 per ton for plate, $67 per ton for beams and $49 per ton for sheet. The first quarter 2015 performance of our raw materials segment includes an operating loss of approximately $44 million or $0.09 per diluted share in our new DRI facility in Louisiana. That is larger than the approximately $35 million operating loss Nucor Steel Louisiana experienced in the fourth quarter. Our Louisiana team has completed repairs and adjustments to the process gas feeder that failed in November of last year. Operations resumed during the last week of the first quarter.
On the positive side, our downstream products segment continues to capitalize on the slow but steady growth underway in nonresidential construction markets. As expected, the segment's first quarter profitability decreased from the fourth quarter level due to typical seasonal factors. However, compared with the year ago quarter, segment pretax profitability increased to more than $32 million from less than $2 million. Particularly strong profit improvement was achieved in our joist and decking and metal building systems businesses.
Quick comments about our tax rate, which can be confusing, due to the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. After adjusting out profits belonging to our business partners, the effective tax rate was 33.9% for the first quarter. Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 36% at the close of the first quarter.
Cash and short-term investments totaled $1.3 billion, including our net debt to capital ratio at approximately 28%. Our net significant debt maturities is not until December 2017.
Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes a $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until August of 19 -- of 2018. Nucor is the only North American steel producer to hold an investment-grade credit rating.
Nucor continues to generate very robust operating cash flow throughout the cyclical up and downs that characterize the steel business. With our highly variable cost structure, we benefit from significant reductions in working capital during downturns. That was the case again in the first quarter of 2015, with cash provided by operations of $564 million, a dramatic increase from the year-ago first quarter. Our strong cash flow allows us to increase our liquidity and retire the year-end 2014 commercial paper balance of about $150 million that had been issued to fund a portion of the Gallatin Steel acquisition in the fourth quarter of last year.
First quarter of 2015 capital expenditures totaled $70 million. We continue to estimate full year 2015 capital spending will be approximately $500 million. Most of our recent largest scale growth projects have been completed or are nearing completion.
Depreciation and amortization for 2015 is expected to total about $700 million.
John made an excellent point about the strength of Nucor's business model. It is one that enjoys competitive advantages and a degree of flexibility that cannot be matched by any of our competitors in the North American steel industry. Nucor's strong balance sheet, consistently healthy cash flow generation and conservative financial practices are critical components of our business model. Times of adversity such as what our industry is currently undergoing, once again, highlight the strength and value of Nucor's significant competitive advantages and superior adaptability. Our focus is not on survival but on growing stronger.
Earnings in the second quarter of 2015 are expected to be somewhat improved from the first quarter. The second quarter should be followed by further improvement in the second half of 2015, given the ongoing strength of nonresidential construction and its impact on our steel mills and downstream businesses. Nonresidential construction activity accounts for more than half of the end-use demand for our products. Margin in the steel mills segment are expected to improve, although we are -- we will not realize the full benefits of lower raw material costs until there is greater stability in steel pricing. As service centers stocking runs its course during this transition period, steel prices are expected to stabilize and rebound. Second quarter performance at our raw material segment will reflect continued high losses at the Louisiana DRI facility and the impact of a nearly completed 1-month maintenance outage at our DRI facility in Trinidad. Our Louisiana plant has resumed production and will be consuming higher cost iron ore that was on hand when the plant suspended operations following a failure in its process gas heater in early November. Our steel products segment is expected to achieve continued improvement in profitability during the second quarter. All 3 major fabricated construction products, joist and decking, fabricated rebar and mill buildings are experiencing significant year-over-year gains in bookings, backlogs and backlog margins. Over the past several months, our confidence has increased that the overall U.S. nonresidential construction market is set to deliver square footage growth in the range of at least 7% to 8% in 2015. Such a growth rate would still place the market almost 40% below the peak level of 2007.
Whatever short-term economic and steel industry conditions we face for the remainder of 2015, Nucor's unrivaled position of strength will allow our team to continue to execute on our proven strategies for delivering profitable, long-term growth and shareholder returns. We appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Nucor's culture has always been defined by our willingness to tackle and overcome challenges. We don't ignore problems. That's not an effective strategy for success or even survival. When confronted by challenges, we find ways to grow stronge
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Nucor's culture has always been defined by our willingness to tackle and overcome challenges. We don't ignore problems. That's not an effective strategy for success or even survival. When confronted by challenges, we find ways to grow stronger, while fixing or mitigating the problem. During the first quarter, unprecedented volumes of steel entrants continued to be a major challenge for our industry. Blatant barring government support of their steel industries has resulted in a glut of global steel production. A brazen disregard for international trade rules has led to the dumping of steel products in our market. As a result, 1:3 tons of steel sold in the U.S. today is produced abroad by a less efficient, less safe and less environmentally friendly countries. This is a real crisis for our industry. We are attacking this issue head-on and fighting back. Nucor's working on a bipartisan basis with Members of Congress and with the administration to ensure that we have a strong and effective tools to combat unfair trade. If Congress passes trade promotion authority legislation authorizing the president to enter into new free trade agreements, we believe the bill must be balanced with the strongest possible trade enforcement mechanisms so that steel and other industries have the tools we need to fight this blatant disregard for international trade rules. There is substantial part from both Democrat and Republicans for doing this. Additionally, the administration must take a much tougher line with countries that break the law. We have a set of rules governing trade. We follow those rules. When foreign countries and producers break those rules, there must be meaningful consequences. Applying tariffs and other remedies is simply holding governments accountable for the agreements that they sign. To that end, Nucor continues to assess market conditions and will be proactive and aggressive in pursuing trade cases when and where it is appropriate.
I will now update you on some of our team's organic growth initiatives underway to improve our long-term course position and expand our product portfolios to include more value-added, higher-margin offerings that are less impacted by the tsunami of imports. After restarting operations at the end of the first quarter, Nucor Steel Louisiana is once again producing DRI at world-class quality levels that our team established prior to the equipment failure. It is important to note that the process gas heaters is not part of the DRI technology utilized by Louisiana, but it is ancillary industrial equipment required to operate plant. During Louisiana's just-completed shutdown, modifications to the process gas heater's original design were implemented to prevent the reoccurrence of a similar failure. One significant modification was the insulation of 2 large dampeners to enable the process gas heater to control its cooling rate which will expand the life of the tubes that have failed in the past. Another significant modification was the addition of a nitrogen purge to the outlet of the heater to significantly reduce any collateral damage in the event of any future tube failure. Louisiana has been a challenging startup. Nevertheless, it is a major step forward in the implementation of our long-term strategy to optimize our iron unit costs. In fact, we believe it has already provided short-term benefits. Presence of our leading DRI facility, having produced 1.3 million tons last year and preparing to resume production at the end of last quarter, was a meaningful factor supporting February's dramatic downward adjustment of more than $100 per ton in scrap prices. That very much supports our I belief in the long-term benefit of our DRI investment.
In the first quarter of 2015, our Hertford County, North Carolina plate mills recently added heat treating and normalizing assets, continued to run at full capacity of approximately 245,000 tons annually. The Hertford County team is capturing a growing share of value-added and higher-margin plate products. Relative to an investment of approximately $150 million, our value-added capabilities offer incremental, pretax profit that should average $200 per ton with the cycle.
During the first quarter, the first field installation of Nucor-Yamato's new wider, sheet piling sections was successfully completed. This new product is the result of a $115 million project we started up in the fourth quarter of last year. Our customers will benefit from this new domestic piling solution as they pursue by-American, government-funded infrastructure projects.
Nucor-Yamato's expanded product portfolio will also create valuable synergies with the other products and services offered by the Skyline Steel piling distribution business we acquired in 2012. Our goal over the next several years is to grow our wider piling sections annual volume to 100,000 tons, which combines steel mill and distribution pretax profit potential of approximately $450 per ton.
Momentum continues to build at Nucor Steel Berkeley's $98 million, wide light capital project that started off in early 2004 and has shipped approximately 120,000 tons last year. We expect to ship about 200,000 tons of the new products in 2015 and eventually grow volume to be at least 300,000 tons annually, with pretax profit averaging $100 per ton through the cycle. Berkeley now has the lightest, hot roll gauge capability of any sheet mill in the southern United States market. And with a finished width capability of up to 72 inches. Of particular importance, the upgrade allows Nucor to produce thinner, high strength steel grades that we plan to use to develop lightweight automotive applications.
As I've said earlier, these are just some of the growth initiatives. I look forward to updating you again next quarter on our progress implementing our strategy for profitable growth.
Here are some of the reasons why I believe Nucor will continue to deliver profitable, long-term growth and industry-leading returns on capital. Our loan and highly variable core structure is Nucor's bedrock competitive advantage. We understand that to generate attractive returns in a commodity business, you have to be a low-cost producer and seek continual improvement in your cost structure. Our balance sheet strength and through the cycle of cash flow generation underpins our long-term focus and ability to take advantage of profitable growth opportunities, particularly during cyclical downturns. Our upstream, vertical integration into raw materials enhances the profitability and flexibility of Nucor's core steelmaking business. The David J. Joseph Company's unmatched global raw material supply chain, combined with our investments in DRI and scrap yards is Nucor's best-in-class capability and flexibility in optimizing what is by far among our largest single cost item, iron units.
Our industry-leading product and market diversity continues to grow as we move up the value chain in all of our businesses. Our downstream vertical integration into value-added steel products enhances the profitability and flexibility of Nucor's core steelmaking business. Our expanded channels to market, such as Harris Steel, Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel increase our ability to compete with unfairly traded imports by expanding our opportunities to add value to our customers. Our commitment to achieving commercial excellence by leveraging Nucor's competitive advantages such as product diversity and operational flexibility to create more value for, and build stronger relationships with, each of our customers. And most importantly, Nucor's employees. The right people. They embraced Nucor culture's pay-for-performance philosophy and passion for continuous improvement in taking care of our customers, our shareholders and their fellow teammates. That is why they're our company's greatest asset and our greatest competitive advantage. As has been true throughout Nucor's history, our company's best years are ahead of us. Thank you for your interest in Nucor. We would now be happy to take your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Luke Folta with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Luke Folta with Jefferies.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, can you help me bridge the gap between the commentary around your nonres construction improvement and the shipment levels in the first quarter? If I look at some of the key categories, the structurals and even in the joist and deck arena and on the
componenttext: John, can you help me bridge the gap between the commentary around your nonres construction improvement and the shipment levels in the first quarter? If I look at some of the key categories, the structurals and even in the joist and deck arena and on the bar business, there's some fairly healthy decline year-over-year. Could you just give us some color on what that's driven by? Is that mostly an import issue? Or is it timing?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's actually a combination of imports and timing. You're comparing it to first quarter of 2014. And if we focus on one, let's pick structural, but for the most part...
componenttext: Well, it's actually a combination of imports and timing. You're comparing it to first quarter of 2014. And if we focus on one, let's pick structural, but for the most part...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think he was comparing to the fourth quarter.
componenttext: I think he was comparing to the fourth quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Were you comparing to the first quarter or the fourth quarter of last year?
componenttext: Were you comparing to the first quarter or the fourth quarter of last year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm looking at year-on-year. 1Q to 1Q.
componenttext: I'm looking at year-on-year. 1Q to 1Q.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, my bad.
componenttext: Okay, my bad.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if we focus on one particular area, let's just take structural, the reasons are basically the same for all of the categories. But at the beginning of 2014, we're looking at a situation where, as you said, imports were much lower. Service center invento
componenttext: So if we focus on one particular area, let's just take structural, the reasons are basically the same for all of the categories. But at the beginning of 2014, we're looking at a situation where, as you said, imports were much lower. Service center inventories were down. We were going into a year where nonresidential construction was projected to be up. Frankly, in the first quarter, we were talking about price increases that were out there. So a combination of all of those resulted in much higher order entry rates within the first quarter of last year compared to the first quarter of this year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if you look at the full year expectation, Jim, I think you said square footage, you expected to grow about 7% to 8% this year. Would you -- I mean outside of the first quarter issue, as it pertains to destocking in imports, would you expect
componenttext: Okay. And then if you look at the full year expectation, Jim, I think you said square footage, you expected to grow about 7% to 8% this year. Would you -- I mean outside of the first quarter issue, as it pertains to destocking in imports, would you expect that these categories should grow about in line with that pace?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again taking imports out of the equation, if we see the growth that we're projecting in nonresidential construction, we should see volume increases compared to the first quarter, particularly as we move out of the seasonal issues that are affecting the fi
componenttext: Again taking imports out of the equation, if we see the growth that we're projecting in nonresidential construction, we should see volume increases compared to the first quarter, particularly as we move out of the seasonal issues that are affecting the first quarter in a lot of our businesses. Particularly, when you look at some of the downstream businesses such as Harris, where frankly it's hard to do a lot of construction work in the first quarter, January and February, and many of our Harris facilities are located in Canada, just to kind of amplify the situation. So we do expect it to improve as we come out of the first quarter. Weather conditions improve. And we see the expected increase in nonresidential construction.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just secondly on DRI, understanding that we've got high cost inventory to work through and that impacts unit costs and the outage as well. If we -- imagine a scenario where we stay in the sort of $260, $275 pig iron environment and iron ore is $
componenttext: Okay. And just secondly on DRI, understanding that we've got high cost inventory to work through and that impacts unit costs and the outage as well. If we -- imagine a scenario where we stay in the sort of $260, $275 pig iron environment and iron ore is $50, can you give us some sense of how we should think about profitability of DRI at full production? Is it profitable meaningfully at that level?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would be cash positive at those levels. When you're talking about pig iron at $250. We do transfer DRI on the pricing mechanism that's based upon pig iron. And I would say that at a level of about $250 for pig iron, we are cash positive. I would also p
componenttext: It would be cash positive at those levels. When you're talking about pig iron at $250. We do transfer DRI on the pricing mechanism that's based upon pig iron. And I would say that at a level of about $250 for pig iron, we are cash positive. I would also point, though I'd be quick to point out that I personally believe $250 for pig iron is an unsustainable level. It's the result of some significant and unusual currency issues and the geopolitical issues. So I personally would not expect that to stay at that low level long term. Having said all of that, we've said from the beginning when we talked about the DRI project, that over the course of the cycles, there's going to be times when we get singles, times when we bunt and some times when we have grand slams. We talked just last quarter about the -- a very positive contribution from our Trinidad operation, when pig iron was at a more normalized rate. And we expect it to be back up to those levels again, and we expect to see very good returns on our DRI investment when that occurs.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to make sure I can understand the -- what happened between your initial qualitative guidance to the quantitative guidance to the beat? Can you just talk us through what changed in your assumptions or what changed in the market environment to change
componenttext: I want to make sure I can understand the -- what happened between your initial qualitative guidance to the quantitative guidance to the beat? Can you just talk us through what changed in your assumptions or what changed in the market environment to change the outcome?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, we can do that. As always, on these things, there's many, many factors. But the key one, the driver for all this was frankly the steel performance, the performance of our steel mill. We've -- we -- in forecasting, we underestimated the impact t
componenttext: Certainly, we can do that. As always, on these things, there's many, many factors. But the key one, the driver for all this was frankly the steel performance, the performance of our steel mill. We've -- we -- in forecasting, we underestimated the impact that we would have on our margins of scrap pricing going down. We got through with -- realize the lower scrap price quicker. And frankly, in some of our products, we had higher volumes. So the combination of an improved margin relative to our forecast and some volume increases above our forecast, we did beat the forecast, as you mentioned.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So 2 questions just to finish up, then fall out of that, is one, why did prices fall less than sheet than they did in plate and beams? It's very high profile to see how much sheet prices have fallen recently but plate and beams, I thought, would be
componenttext: Okay. So 2 questions just to finish up, then fall out of that, is one, why did prices fall less than sheet than they did in plate and beams? It's very high profile to see how much sheet prices have fallen recently but plate and beams, I thought, would be -- fall just more recently with the $100 scrap move in just in February. So why did you see plates and beams fall more than you did in sheet in the quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, one element that you have to take into account when you -- to answer that question is some portion of our sheet business is on quarter-over-quarter contract pricing that's based on some mechanism. So when you -- there's a lag time before you see tha
componenttext: Well, one element that you have to take into account when you -- to answer that question is some portion of our sheet business is on quarter-over-quarter contract pricing that's based on some mechanism. So when you -- there's a lag time before you see that decrease in those contract pricing. I would also point out that although the import situation is very serious on sheet product, particularly plate, there's just been an unbelievable tsunami of imports -- imported plate over the last 2 quarters. And that of course had a dramatic impact on our pricing of plate.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And the other thing I wanted to ask is just -- maybe it's philosophical but I've just been surprised at how -- I know prices always overcorrect in a down market, but why would a company like a mini mill like yourselves, you have the
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And the other thing I wanted to ask is just -- maybe it's philosophical but I've just been surprised at how -- I know prices always overcorrect in a down market, but why would a company like a mini mill like yourselves, you have the flexibility to ramp down, continue to produce at these very low prices and to match imports? Isn't there a price at which you say, no, I don't want to make that low a margin, and I'm going to hold out and it's -- you know that prices are expected to recover. Why is everybody, including yourselves, I guess, continue to produce and offer these low-priced tons at import levels, at import equivalent levels? What do you think?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's always a balance, right? You want to look at your -- the volume you put through your facility, which obviously impacts your fixed costs of that facility. So that's one issue. Secondly, we need to take care of our customers. We don't want to giv
componenttext: Well, it's always a balance, right? You want to look at your -- the volume you put through your facility, which obviously impacts your fixed costs of that facility. So that's one issue. Secondly, we need to take care of our customers. We don't want to give up market share. Sometimes, when you lose a customer or lose a business opportunity, it's hard to regain it. And we -- our customers count on us being there even when it's a difficult pricing environment. So those are couple of reasons that we continue to operate. I'll also point out that, Timna, and let know if I didn't answer that question, if I didn't, cover what you wanted to hear on that. But given the radical change in the scrap costs, which we frankly believe were coming because of the large gap between scrap price and iron units, we felt that we could work our way through those tough times, keep our customers satisfied, maintain our market share, not lose good opportunities, knowing that we would ultimately be able to, as a result of scrap costs going down, be able to correct, our pricing and get it closer to the market, to the imported price and maintain a margin.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on trade. So it seems like you're taking kind of a two-pronged or maybe the industry's taking a two-pronged approach to trade issues. One is just putting together a trade case we keep hearing about on flat rolled. But the other is on
componenttext: My first question is on trade. So it seems like you're taking kind of a two-pronged or maybe the industry's taking a two-pronged approach to trade issues. One is just putting together a trade case we keep hearing about on flat rolled. But the other is on the legislative front. Senator Brown has got these leveling the playing field rules that is, I assume, trying to attach to the TPA at this point. So it seems like maybe there's a chance you get to some of these rules that would actually change the way that the harm is measured in the U.S. through in the next few months here. How do those 2 things impact one or the other? So my question is, would you wait to file a trade case on flat rolls if you think you can maybe change the rules at the ITC on the harm decision? Or are those completely independent?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: When we fight, we use both fists, okay? So those are our two-pronged approach, and we're going to use both of those prongs to achieve a level playing field so that our teammates can be successful, which we know they will be in on a level playing field. I
componenttext: When we fight, we use both fists, okay? So those are our two-pronged approach, and we're going to use both of those prongs to achieve a level playing field so that our teammates can be successful, which we know they will be in on a level playing field. I mentioned on the last couple of calls that I felt we were gaining traction in Washington on both of those fronts. I still do. We are getting a much better reception. People are beginning to understand. I believe people are beginning to understand the impact of these illegally traded products on our industry and on our teammates and steelworkers in general. It's about focusing and pursuing trade cases when it's appropriate and moving forward on the legislative front at the same time. We see great opportunity, frankly, on the legislative front, particularly with the TPA discussions that are going on today. We are pushing very, very hard and getting good reception on both sides of the aisle to the concept that if TPA is going to be approved, it must be approved with strong trade language to protect our industries and give us the ability to better and more effectively and more proactively fight illegally traded products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just maybe on the trade case. What's kind of your outlook there on timing? It seems like it's been a pretty weak first quarter for most folks at this point. And second quarter probably for most folks will also obviously be clearly difficul
componenttext: Great. And then just maybe on the trade case. What's kind of your outlook there on timing? It seems like it's been a pretty weak first quarter for most folks at this point. And second quarter probably for most folks will also obviously be clearly difficult. Do you think the case is ready to bring at this point? Or do you think need to demonstrate more harm before the industry's comfortable filing?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me be clear. We will continue to assess the market, and we will implement the trade case at the appropriate time.
componenttext: Let me be clear. We will continue to assess the market, and we will implement the trade case at the appropriate time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just one last one quickly on scrap. What's your view for the upcoming month? It seems like flows maybe are starting to pick up a little bit, which would be negative, and maybe demand is coming back. Where do you think it all shakes ou
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just one last one quickly on scrap. What's your view for the upcoming month? It seems like flows maybe are starting to pick up a little bit, which would be negative, and maybe demand is coming back. Where do you think it all shakes out?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly, our forecast would be pretty flat line for the rest of the year. Obviously, when you talk about scrap, there's always slightly -- slight variations in different regions. We expect some movements in different regions, up 5, down 10, so forth
componenttext: Well, frankly, our forecast would be pretty flat line for the rest of the year. Obviously, when you talk about scrap, there's always slightly -- slight variations in different regions. We expect some movements in different regions, up 5, down 10, so forth, as we go throughout the year. But overall, as you look at the year as a whole, I think we're going to be pretty flat line on scrap pricing.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Matthew Korn with Barclays.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Matthew Korn with Barclays.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me ask, how much of your lead times improved today, say, versus the bottom of this previous quarter? And how deeply are you sold into May, June, particularly as you're expecting much better results from the downstream segment looking ahead?
componenttext: Let me ask, how much of your lead times improved today, say, versus the bottom of this previous quarter? And how deeply are you sold into May, June, particularly as you're expecting much better results from the downstream segment looking ahead?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've mentioned in the script, this is a quarter of transition. So we're not quite sure when we'll see that actual kick in. Today, there's, I would say, a very modest improvement in lead times, very modest, frankly not significantly over first qu
componenttext: Well, as we've mentioned in the script, this is a quarter of transition. So we're not quite sure when we'll see that actual kick in. Today, there's, I would say, a very modest improvement in lead times, very modest, frankly not significantly over first quarter. And that would expand -- that will go across -- that would apply to all -- basically all of our products. Now the one exception I would add to that is in the sheet side on the galvanizing and cold rolled products, those lead times are longer, and we still see a pretty strong demand in that area.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So kind of following up to that, and on your volume expectations, gradual construction and order demand improvements. When you're looking into this transitional second quarter, is the improvement in earnings really going to be mostly a margin e
componenttext: All right. So kind of following up to that, and on your volume expectations, gradual construction and order demand improvements. When you're looking into this transitional second quarter, is the improvement in earnings really going to be mostly a margin expansion story on the realization of lower scrap costs? Or could you see some real volume improvement?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's combination of the 2. And again, to kind of divvy it out further than that, be more specific than that, very difficult to do. But I would say it's a combination of both.
componenttext: I'd say it's combination of the 2. And again, to kind of divvy it out further than that, be more specific than that, very difficult to do. But I would say it's a combination of both.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Matt Murphy with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Matt Murphy with UBS.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Was just wondering what your capacity utilization is right now if it was 65% on average for Q1. Would it be lower than that now?
componenttext: Was just wondering what your capacity utilization is right now if it was 65% on average for Q1. Would it be lower than that now?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's about the same. I can't speak to what it is exactly today. But so far, we've been about the same.
componenttext: It's about the same. I can't speak to what it is exactly today. But so far, we've been about the same.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And is that -- I mean I guess I'm just wondering what the -- does the recovery profile of that, like we basically be watching imports coming off to drive that back out?
componenttext: Yes, okay. And is that -- I mean I guess I'm just wondering what the -- does the recovery profile of that, like we basically be watching imports coming off to drive that back out?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, there will be a number of factors. Imports beginning to drop off, although we have seen them, I want to stress that it's going to be a while before we see the dropoff. Although we've seen a slight decline in licenses, there was so much out th
componenttext: Well, again, there will be a number of factors. Imports beginning to drop off, although we have seen them, I want to stress that it's going to be a while before we see the dropoff. Although we've seen a slight decline in licenses, there was so much out there in the pipeline that this is going to take off. And so much has already reached the service centers and just build up their inventories. It's going to be a while before we work our way through that. Now I can tell you that for the first time, this month, the numbers that just came out on service center inventories, we see them being down just a little bit. But imports are something you should certainly watch, and there are other factors, too, particularly our sheet business, when you want to look at oil price. Now I can't tell you when it's going to recover, but certainly, we've seen a tremendous impact on our flat roll business as a result of oil pricing going from $100 to $50. Our volumes are way down. Same situation there. We flooded the pipeline with material. There's been a complete stop as they work their way through this inventory at some point. I frankly don't think it will be in the second quarter, but some point during the course of the year, maybe third or fourth quarter. We'll start working our way through that inventory, and we see order rates that are consistent with the new normal drilling levels that are expected with the lower price. Another thing you can keep your eye on is currency. Obviously, the strong dollar has an impact on what's happening both on our raw material side and on our steel shipment side as it relates to imports and other factors. So I tried to give you a couple of things that you can keep an eye on, but there's a multitude of things that we have to watch to see what's going to happen as we go forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, that's a good color. I mean I'm basically just sort of looking at like is this a 3-month thing or a 6-month thing but I understand it's dependent on all those factors. I guess on scrap prices, I've been a little bit surprised that no one is expec
componenttext: Yes. No, that's a good color. I mean I'm basically just sort of looking at like is this a 3-month thing or a 6-month thing but I understand it's dependent on all those factors. I guess on scrap prices, I've been a little bit surprised that no one is expecting, it seems, much more weakness there, given we had seen a continued iron ore weakness. So I guess just on scrap, what's the confidence that we've got some pricing stability for a while here?
