headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Second Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Second Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of the date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
For opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other Executiv
componenttext: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other Executive Vice Presidents: Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski and Chad Utermark. The entire executive team would like to thank you all, all of our team members on Harris, Nucor, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, Newbridge Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for your excellent work taking care of our customers and implementing our company strategy for long-term profitable growth. Without question, the first half of 2015 has been an extremely challenging time for the steel industry. The strategy at Nucor is about growing stronger and building the foundation for higher highs in earnings. Our unrivaled competitive advantages and highly flexible business model allow us to manage our business with a long-term focus on profitable and sustainable growth. Just as important, the financial success of our employees is tightly aligned with that of our shareholders. That is why the more than 23,000 men and women of the Nucor team apply both their high energy level and sense of urgency to achieving our goal of profitable growth. We have a lot of exciting progress to share with you today. But first, I will ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to review Nucor's second quarter performance and financial position. Following Jim's comments, I will update you on the execution of our strategy for long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Second quarter of 2015 earnings of $0.39 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.20 to $0.25 per diluted share. Second quarter results included a benefit of approximately $0.03 per diluted share related to state tax credits that
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Second quarter of 2015 earnings of $0.39 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.20 to $0.25 per diluted share. Second quarter results included a benefit of approximately $0.03 per diluted share related to state tax credits that largely arose from recently completed capital investment projects, though state tax credits were not factored into our guidance for the quarter. Overall, second quarter out-performance resulted from better-than-expected shipments and margins in our steel mills segment. The effective execution of Nucor's channel-to-market strategy is driving strong relative performance at both our bar and beam mills. Also, our sheet and plate businesses are benefiting from recent investments, allowing us to expand our offerings of value-added and higher-margin products in more demanding and import-resistant applications.
Our downstream product segment continues to capitalize on the slow but steady growth in nonresidential construction markets. Segment profitability for the first 6 months of 2015 was more than double the first half of 2014. Backlogs are also higher over year-ago levels for all 3 of our major fabricated construction products, [indiscernible] decking, rebar application and metal buildings. As measured by square footage, we expect the U.S. nonresidential construction activity in 2015 to increase by approximately 5% to 6% from 2014 levels.
The second quarter of 2015 performance of our raw materials segment included an operating loss at our new facility in Louisiana for approximately $20 million. That was down from the first quarter operating loss of approximately $44 million. The quarter-over-quarter improvement resulted from the strong output achieved following last quarter's restart production and a better product payment of approximately $10 million. Nucor Steel Louisiana's second quarter results included a negative impact of consuming higher-cost iron ore inventory that was acquired in 2014. As we disclosed in our first quarter conference call, we expect to finish working through those higher-cost raw materials by the close of the third quarter.
A quick comment about our tax rates since they can be confusing due to the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. After adjusting our profits belonging to our business partners and the $9.3 million benefit related to state tax credits, the effective tax rate was 36.4% for the second quarter. Nucor continued to generate very robust operating cash flow during extremely challenging first half of 2015. With the highly variable and low cost structure, we benefit from significant reductions in working capital during downturns. That was the case again in the first half of 2015, with cash provided by operations of approximately $1.2 billion, a dramatic increase from the year-ago first half's operating cash flow of $443 million. Nucor's strong through-the-cycle operating cash flow generation allows us to invest in attractive opportunities during periods of industry distress, when the long-term returns are most attractive and to continue rewarding our shareholders with immediate returns in the form of base dividends that increased for 42 consecutive years.
Here's some numbers that help explain our cash generation such an important competitive strength supporting our team's focus on profitable long-term growth. Over the past 4 quarters, Nucor's generated cash from operations totaling $2.1 billion. During that period, that cash flow has enabled us to fund the acquisition of Gallatin Steel for about $779 million, paid cash dividends to shareholders of $477 million, investing capital expenditures of $391 -- $381 million, excuse me, let me repeat that, the invested capital expenditures of $381 million and increase our liquidity. In this time of unprecedented industry turmoil, our focus is not on survival but on growing the long-term value of our shareholders' investments. Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 36% at the close of the second quarter.
Cash and short-term investments totaled $1.7 billion, putting our net debt-to-capital ratio at approximately 26%. Our next significant debt maturity is not until December 2017. Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. That facility does not mature until August of 2018. Nucor is the only North American steel producer to hold an investment-grade credit rating.
The first 6 months of 2015 capital expenditures totaled $163 billion. We estimate full year 2015 capital spending will be approximately $450 million. Most of our recent larger-scale organic growth investments have been completed or are nearing completion.
Depreciation and amortization for 2015 is expected to total about $700 million. Earnings in the third quarter of 2015 are expected to be improved from second quarter. The steel segment should benefit from beginning the quarter with lower-cost inventories. Our steel product segment is expected to benefit from continuing gradual improvement in nonresidential construction activity. We are confident Nucor's significant competitive advantages and highly adaptable business model will allow our team to continue to execute our proven strategies for delivering profitable long-term growth and shareholder returns.
We do appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Nucor's long-time success has been achieved by focusing on a simple strategy. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength in gaining profitable market share in our core businesses of steel and steel products throughout the economi
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Nucor's long-time success has been achieved by focusing on a simple strategy. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength in gaining profitable market share in our core businesses of steel and steel products throughout the economic cycle. Anchored to our strategy and its execution are these very powerful competitive strengths of Nucor. Nucor is a low-cost producer of steel and steel products. Importantly, we work to drive continual improvement in our cost structure. Nucor's financial strength is unparalleled in the North American steel industry. Nucor generates robust operating cash flow throughout the cyclical ups and downs that are inevitable part of the steel business. Nucor is the market leader in 9 of the 11 largest markets where we compete. Market leadership matters as we are able to earn higher margins by providing the broadest mix of products and services to our customers.
Nucor's channel-to-the-market strategy allows our steel mills to increase their penetration of higher margin and higher value-added products in a global steel market burdened with irrational excess capacity resulting from foreign government subsidies. Nucor's raw material strategy of execution has positioned us with greater flexibility to take advantage of the lowest-cost feedstock for making steel in a commodity business characterized by high volatility and infill costs. The steel industry has seen some very tough times over the past nearly 7 years, stretching back to the fall of 2008. While Nucor certainly does not welcome tough times in our business, we do not fear them. In fact, we use them to our advantage to grow stronger. I'm pleased to report that Nucor's position of strength has improved during this protracted steel industry downturn. Since 2008, Nucor has invested almost $6 billion to expand our portfolio to higher-margin products and to improve our relative cost position. Given the growth in our earnings capacity and the strength of the steel market demand in the U.S., we believe our profitability will challenge and possibly exceed our 2008 record earnings level, were it not for the tsunami of illegally traded influence that are overwhelming domestic steel industry. Nevertheless, the very initial payoff from these investments already can be seen on our current results. Here are some examples: Nucor's market-leading long products businesses achieved year-over-year growth and profitability for both the second quarter and first half of 2015 despite significant marketplace pressures resulting from influence. The key to this performance are market leadership positions and our vertically integrated, channel-to-the-market strategy. Our bar milles benefited from our strong channels to market provided by our downstream businesses. These downstream channels to market include: our market-leading joist-and-decking operations; our Harris Steel rebar fabrication business; our market-leading cold finish bar business; our market-leading pre-engineered metal buildings business; and a few others. Our Nucor-Yamato steel mill delivered a particularly strong performance through the second quarter. This performance is evidenced of the strong partnerships Nucor-Yamato Steel has built with its fabricated customers. Also, the market-leading teams at Nucor-Yamato Steel and Skyline Steel continue to grow profitable market share for us in the steel piping market. Nucor-Yamato Steel expects to grow wider island sections annual volume to 100,000 tons over the next few years. These products were introduced to the marketplace earlier this year and received their first extra order in the second quarter.
The automotive market continues to be an attractive growth opportunity for Nucor. Our sheets and engineered bar businesses are on track in 2015 to increase their combined automotive volume by more than 20% to approximately 1.4 million tons. And there is more growth ahead as our goal is to reach an annual shipment rate of 2 million tons to the automotive market within the next 2 to 3 years. As always, our focus is on profitable growth in our automotive book of business, created by our ability to provide unique, value-added products and services. Nucor's recent and significant investments throughout our sheet and engineered bar mill groups are driving our growing market share in these higher-margin and more import-resistant products.
Our Nucor Steel Berkeley sheet mills continued to build momentum in the second quarter with its very successful rollout of new wide line products. Berkeley expects to ship 200,000 tons of these new products this year, allowing it to gain market share with a number of important heavy equipment service centers and automotive customers. Completed in 2014, the wide line modernization capital project has positioned Berkeley with the lightest capability of any sheet mill in the Southern U.S. market and with the finished product lift of up to 72 inches.
Our raw material strategy is a critical foundation, supporting Nucor's growing participation in higher value-added and higher-margin products. During the second quarter, our Louisiana directly produced iron plant successfully ramped up its -- following its 5-month shutdown to make major equipment improvements. Louisiana produced approximately 540,000 tons of DRI in the second quarter of 2015 with its usual world-class quality levels. Louisiana has been a challenging start-up as was our plan to Trinidad that started up in 2007. It is worth noting that the challenge is in Trinidad was somewhat masked by dramatically different raw materials striking environment. Despite recent challenges, our confidence has never been higher regarding the long-term value of Nucor owning DRI production capability. It puts Nucor in unrivaled position of flexibility in optimizing our iron units cost during the cycle. During the second quarter, major progress was achieved in the work done by Nucor and other producers to fight back against the tsunami of illegally traded steel influence coming into the United States. Influx was 32% of all steel sold in this country in the first 6 months of this year. That is up from a 27% market share for the year-ago period and slightly above 20% of the market in 2009.
I am very pleased to report that we scored 2 significant victories recently. Congress, on a bipartisan basis, adopted important trade remedy provisions championed by the U.S. steel industry as part of a package of trade bills. By passing this legislation, Congress has given our industry more effective tools to fight back against unfairly and illegally traded steel influence. These changes were long overdue. The U.S. trade laws have not been updated for over 20 years. The Nucor team implores Congress and the administration take a much tougher line with countries that break the law and destroy the economic vitality of our country. These new trade laws alone will not address the underlying issue of systemic global steel overcapacity resulting from trade distorting practices of some foreign governments. It is time for the world trading community to take firm action to stop these countries from dumping their steel and force them to comply with World Trade Organization rules. As has always been the case, Nucor will not hesitate to file a trade case if the evidence warrants such action. During the second quarter, we joined 5 other steel makers in filing a trade case against India, China, Italy, Korea and Taiwan for dumping and providing significant subsidies to producers of corrosion-resistant steel. We are pleased that last week, the U.S. International Trade Commission made a preliminary affirmative determination allowing the case to proceed. Nucor will continue to assess market conditions in other products market -- and other part of markets and pursue cases, when appropriate. Our fight against illegally traded steel implements is essential to meeting our responsibility to be an effective steward of our shareholders' valuable capital.
In closing, I am extremely confident that Nucor's best years are still ahead of us. Every time I visit a Nucor facility and spend time with my teammates, I'm reminded why I have absolute confidence that Nucor's future is extremely bright. It's because of the quality and commitment of the men and women who serve together with me on the Nucor team. They are truly the best. They are truly the right people. They will get the job done. Thank you for your interest in Nucor. We will now be happy to take your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Luke Folta with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Luke Folta with Jefferies.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question I had was on nonres. We saw a bit of slowing in terms of -- well, I mean, you saw from a really nice year-over-year growth in joist stack and rebar fab last year in the first quarter, and that seemed to have dropped off quite a bit in 2Q an
componenttext: First question I had was on nonres. We saw a bit of slowing in terms of -- well, I mean, you saw from a really nice year-over-year growth in joist stack and rebar fab last year in the first quarter, and that seemed to have dropped off quite a bit in 2Q and similar things out of Steel Dynamics downstream business yesterday with volumes. The commentary pretty positive around nonres. Can you just give us some sense of what's going on in terms of the shipment levels?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with the overall market. The pundits are still saying that we would expect the 7% to 8% increase in nonres this year over last year. We think that number is a little bit optimistic. We see it close to be around 5% to 6% this year nonres
componenttext: Well, let me start with the overall market. The pundits are still saying that we would expect the 7% to 8% increase in nonres this year over last year. We think that number is a little bit optimistic. We see it close to be around 5% to 6% this year nonresidential construction. As far as our downstream businesses go, we're seeing some very positive things. Our backlogs are stronger than they have ever been. Frankly, the pricing of the products in our backlog is stronger, and we've seen them quite some time. So although we see things over the course of the year slowing a little bit more compared to last year, we're still pretty optimistic about nonresidential construction and our downstream businesses going into it.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And just on the trade side, the language that went into the TPA deal here recently, how big of a deal do you think that is? And when you, I guess, think about the impact from imports, is fair to say that Nucor probably has more upside tha
componenttext: Okay. All right. And just on the trade side, the language that went into the TPA deal here recently, how big of a deal do you think that is? And when you, I guess, think about the impact from imports, is fair to say that Nucor probably has more upside than the industry as a whole in terms of -- if there is a change in the way import protection [indiscernible] enforcement improves here? Do you think that there's more upside just given your southern presence and I think I would guess that more of your business enters into the spot market than maybe some of your integrated peers to the north? So any commentary around that would be helpful.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me respond in general. We think that there's tremendous upside. I won't compare it to any of our competitors. But for us, we're very optimistic about the potential upside. We're very positive about the language in the legislation. Clearly, this
componenttext: Well, let me respond in general. We think that there's tremendous upside. I won't compare it to any of our competitors. But for us, we're very optimistic about the potential upside. We're very positive about the language in the legislation. Clearly, this gives us much stronger tools to fight back against unfair trade. Just to mention maybe a couple of the things that it does for us. Number one, it changes the definition of injury. It gives the International Trade Commission the much broader list of factors on determining whether an industry has been injured, not just profitability. That's important. It's no longer be necessary for us to suffer severe financial damage before action can be taken. Another permission enhances the Commerce's Department -- excuse me, the Commerce Department's discretion in dealing with foreign companies and foreign governments that are uncooperative or very slow to provide the information they need to make a determination. So although I have to say that this is a very positive first step, there is more work to be done and we believe that this will create a much more balanced and fair marketplace competition here in the United States, but there's still work to be done. So we will continue to work in Washington with elected officials and continue to press for even stronger trade laws in the future.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And okay. If I could ask one more just on the raw materials segment outlook. Your Louisiana plant seems like it's ramping up pretty nicely. Entering 3Q, you're not going to have the Trinidad outage, and I would think that the headwind from the high-cost r
componenttext: And okay. If I could ask one more just on the raw materials segment outlook. Your Louisiana plant seems like it's ramping up pretty nicely. Entering 3Q, you're not going to have the Trinidad outage, and I would think that the headwind from the high-cost raw materials would be lesser quarter-on-quarter. Just trying to get sense of what was that you're looking for the flat outcome in that business quarter-to-quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Trinidad will do better. As you mentioned, we won't have to shut down that. In the case in Louisiana, it will probably be towards the end of the third quarter by the time we work through all of the high-priced inventory. And the reason that it might
componenttext: Well, Trinidad will do better. As you mentioned, we won't have to shut down that. In the case in Louisiana, it will probably be towards the end of the third quarter by the time we work through all of the high-priced inventory. And the reason that it might be the same even with the improvement in Trinidad is that we won't see the same impact as we did with the $10 million payment on a vendor liability.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-ups on the trade front. So I was just wondering, so the world's now changed as far as injury definition goes. Does that mean that some of the trade cases that people have been working on for the past, I guess, year-plus now in hot
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-ups on the trade front. So I was just wondering, so the world's now changed as far as injury definition goes. Does that mean that some of the trade cases that people have been working on for the past, I guess, year-plus now in hot rolled, cold rolled that haven't really seen, that have to be rewritten to kind of match the new rules? Is that going to cause some sort of a delay?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Frankly, just the opposite. As we go forward and we press for any potential cases that we might file in the future. What will happen is the new law will apply to them. So it will not cause delays. If anything, just the opposite will happen. Now the co
componenttext: No. Frankly, just the opposite. As we go forward and we press for any potential cases that we might file in the future. What will happen is the new law will apply to them. So it will not cause delays. If anything, just the opposite will happen. Now the countries that we would potentially file against will be required to submit the data faster. We will not have the same list of reasons why they cannot get the data in a timely manner. And as we look at pressing the point of further there was injury or not, there's a different set of guidelines that will be used. Certainly, this will not cause any delay. But if anything, we expect it to speed up the process and in cases that we've pressed in the future.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then from what I understand, there's actually some additional trade protection that we could see coming out of the customs bill that it's in conference right now on the enforcement front. And I understand the language is a little bit different
componenttext: Great. And then from what I understand, there's actually some additional trade protection that we could see coming out of the customs bill that it's in conference right now on the enforcement front. And I understand the language is a little bit different on the Senate side versus the house side on the [indiscernible] bill for some of us on the outside who try to follow this. Do you have some insights there that could help us? Are there any -- is there any particular language that we should be looking at that you really want to see passed on this customs bill? Or is there any language that makes you a little bit more nervous or cautious? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start by saying that we're not going to comment on what the outcome will be in Washington. We will work hard with our elected officials to get an outcome that's favorable to the industry. Beyond that, I don't want to say too much. It's an ong
componenttext: Well, let me start by saying that we're not going to comment on what the outcome will be in Washington. We will work hard with our elected officials to get an outcome that's favorable to the industry. Beyond that, I don't want to say too much. It's an ongoing case, and I don't want to say too much about it at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And maybe one last question on raw materials as well. I'm just trying to get a sense for modeling Louisiana going forward as far as the flow-through on the timing for iron ore inventory. And I fully understand that you had quite a bit o
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And maybe one last question on raw materials as well. I'm just trying to get a sense for modeling Louisiana going forward as far as the flow-through on the timing for iron ore inventory. And I fully understand that you had quite a bit of outages, hiccups getting this project started, and that obviously stretched out the underlying amount of iron ore you have in the ground probably considerably. But once things normalize, how much iron ore inventory would you normally have on the ground? And how quickly should we model in price change on iron ore through your earnings?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, remember, as you factor -- as you think about the fact that we buy iron ore on a contract basis and we pay for the previous quarter. Because there's always a 1-quarter delay between what you're seeing going to the furnace and what you purchase. So a
componenttext: Well, remember, as you factor -- as you think about the fact that we buy iron ore on a contract basis and we pay for the previous quarter. Because there's always a 1-quarter delay between what you're seeing going to the furnace and what you purchase. So always make sure you put the time delay in there as you go forward. We use about 4 million [ph] tons a year. So in terms of keeping the inventory off the ground, we probably have maybe 1 month.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: 1 month.
componenttext: 1 month.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. About 1 million tons we would keep on ground, probably about 25% of our annual use.
componenttext: No, no, no. About 1 million tons we would keep on ground, probably about 25% of our annual use.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Matt Murphy with UBS.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Matt Murphy with UBS.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, you made a comment your backlogs are stronger than you've seen in some time. Structural rebar and joist in Q2 were all kind of flat to down. So I'm just wondering, is the backlog stronger now than it was at the end of Q1? And do you think that's a r
componenttext: John, you made a comment your backlogs are stronger than you've seen in some time. Structural rebar and joist in Q2 were all kind of flat to down. So I'm just wondering, is the backlog stronger now than it was at the end of Q1? And do you think that's a result of underlying demand uplift? Or is it more imports sort of easing off? Or is it a combo of the 2?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ray, why don't you take that?
componenttext: Ray, why don't you take that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ray Napolitan. I would say our downstream backlogs are a combination of several things, an improved underlying demand and overall the slow growth of the nonres market, plus there were some delayed shipments in the first quarter, first half of the
componenttext: This is Ray Napolitan. I would say our downstream backlogs are a combination of several things, an improved underlying demand and overall the slow growth of the nonres market, plus there were some delayed shipments in the first quarter, first half of the year due to weather. But overall, team's doing the job in the increasing our backlog levels in both [indiscernible] second half of the year for all 3 of our major downstream products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, one other question is, when you talk about the flexibility DRI offers -- and I appreciate it. It Probably plays a role in helping the current pricing environment in the scrap market, but presumably, the flexibility means you run i
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, one other question is, when you talk about the flexibility DRI offers -- and I appreciate it. It Probably plays a role in helping the current pricing environment in the scrap market, but presumably, the flexibility means you run it hard when scrap prices are high and you don't focus on it as much when they're low. So I'm just wondering how you think about your raw material strategy as iron ore spirals and maybe we see some more weakness coming in scrap.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you're exactly right. It gives us the ability to switch back and forth, whether it's in scrap or whether it's in DRI, depending upon what's the cost of the iron unit is. At the end of the day, an iron unit is an iron unit. But it does. It gives us t
componenttext: Well, you're exactly right. It gives us the ability to switch back and forth, whether it's in scrap or whether it's in DRI, depending upon what's the cost of the iron unit is. At the end of the day, an iron unit is an iron unit. But it does. It gives us the flexibility to change and modify our feedstock mix so that we can optimize our mix based upon current pricing in the different commodities. It gives us a lot of flexibility. We have pig iron out there. Now we have HBI with gives us DRI. We have scrap that's under our control, so we have a lot of flexibility. What will drive the decision on where we are focusing is the price of the iron unit in each one of those areas.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 bigger lines to touch on. One is we've heard so much about flat roll then and the improvements expected there, and we're kind of surprised of the year-over-year declines in bars, structural and plate. So just wanted to drill down a little bit more if
componenttext: So 2 bigger lines to touch on. One is we've heard so much about flat roll then and the improvements expected there, and we're kind of surprised of the year-over-year declines in bars, structural and plate. So just wanted to drill down a little bit more if you could provide some information on how much of that might be destocking imports or underlying demand.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I can tell you that -- on the buying demand, the United States is very, very strong. But that's not the issue. the issue is in demand on the supply side. And it's a fact that imports so heavy. As I'm sure you know, Timna, they're captured about 32%
componenttext: Well, I can tell you that -- on the buying demand, the United States is very, very strong. But that's not the issue. the issue is in demand on the supply side. And it's a fact that imports so heavy. As I'm sure you know, Timna, they're captured about 32% of the steel market today. And although that we're looking at -- I mean, I'm talking about the whole market there, although we're looking at demand levels that are probability be just about the same as last year, the import level has gone up 27% to about 32% to 33%. So demand is not the issue. Demand is strong. But imports are taking a much bigger bite out of our potential long product business. My thoughts about 32% to 33%, that's across all of our products. And if you look at it, you mentioned being specific, we saw comment on that. Imports are up 33%, which means year-over-year. That's a huge increase. So the short answer to question, demand is strong. We see good demand. We believe that we will grow moderately throughout the rest of the year. The issue has been the influence and I stress, the issue is actually not the influence. The issue is illegally unfairly traded imports.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. The other question I'll ask is just a huge amount of free cash flow in the first half of the year. And I know that Jim stressed the importance of your cash generation as a competitive strength. And not to pick on you, but you did point out
componenttext: Okay, got you. The other question I'll ask is just a huge amount of free cash flow in the first half of the year. And I know that Jim stressed the importance of your cash generation as a competitive strength. And not to pick on you, but you did point out that the DRI is obviously less attractive in the current commodity environment that none of us forecasted [indiscernible] I get that. But if you -- can you talk us a little bit about how you can deploy that capital going forward in ways that we can be confident until grow the business? Do you -- in light of the fact that you've already done a lot of investments to grow organically, do you start steer maybe towards other uses of cash going forward?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that our [indiscernible] is always to invest to grow our business. And we believe that there's still a lot of opportunity to do that and it would focus on areas that both value-added, higher-value products. Investments to commit similar to wha
componenttext: I would say that our [indiscernible] is always to invest to grow our business. And we believe that there's still a lot of opportunity to do that and it would focus on areas that both value-added, higher-value products. Investments to commit similar to what we did on accounting with key treat and the normalizing line come, investments that we made in SBQ, investments that we made at Berkeley with ALIF wide project, the investments that we made with wider piling sections. And all of these occasions we're focusing on investments on higher-margin products but also more import-resistant. Although we're taking a lot, we feel good about action that's being taken in Washington to fight off these illegally traded products. The focus that we have is to continue to work to better insulate Nucor from that flood of imports. And the way to do that is to focus on this value-added products. A good example that I can give you, Timna, is all the work that we're doing on our advanced supply strength steel going to the automotive market. I mentioned how we've done in that over the last couple of years. There's a product as of the quality requirements and because of the just-in-time delivery requirements, that's not easily imported. So that's an area of focus for us. I'd also like to speak a little bit more about the continued investment in lowering our total cost reduction. You mentioned that I referenced our DRI production, given the current environment, is not as attractive as we thought we might have been at one point. But I do want to point out that it's still attractive. If you take a look, the issue we're working on right through is the short-term issue when we have this iron ore that's higher-priced. But if you took a look at the cost of our conversion cost today, and you apply the market price for iron units coming out of iron ore today, our all-in costs will be under what we would have to be paying for other forms of low-residual products like pig iron and prime scrap. So it's [indiscernible] to how you both invest. The question of whether it's a good investment or whether it's a great investment in today's price environment. It's a good investment. In pricing environment of iron units where we were 1.5 years ago, it would be a great investment. And trust me, given the cyclical nature of our business, it will be a great investment again in the future. So I wanted to be clear about that so that should we move forward with investing further in some form of the DRI or blast furnace project, everyone understands that we have a short-term issue. We're dealing with it. It will pass. Long term, we still believe very strongly in the strategy. At the end of the day, we look at it this way. We look at it this way, the amount of iron ore in the world is virtually unlimited. The amount of scrap in the world is much more limited, and it's -- we can generate more iron ore by reinvesting in extraction techniques and stuff to generate more scrap. And we see that, frankly, we see the amount of scrap being generated in the United States that's declining.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, but one of my question wasn't to belabor the DRI issue because there were all good points, and I understand is, I guess, a part of my question was that I'd ask if the use of cash to protect against imports is the primary source or use of cash for th
componenttext: Okay, but one of my question wasn't to belabor the DRI issue because there were all good points, and I understand is, I guess, a part of my question was that I'd ask if the use of cash to protect against imports is the primary source or use of cash for the last several years and yet the benefit of those use has yet to show up, do you start to think about more direct return to shareholders to deploy that capital in a more direct way?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we always look at all options, and we look at the potential investments that we can make in our business. And if we believe that there good investments to make, and we believe that they bring long-term earnings to our shareholders, that's the direct
componenttext: Well, we always look at all options, and we look at the potential investments that we can make in our business. And if we believe that there good investments to make, and we believe that they bring long-term earnings to our shareholders, that's the direction we'll take. On the other hand, if we don't see them out there, we will consider all other options.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: How much sheet capability do you have left for the third quarter?
componenttext: How much sheet capability do you have left for the third quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gee, that might be a different way of asking what's our utilization rate in sheet. Is that where you're going?
componenttext: Gee, that might be a different way of asking what's our utilization rate in sheet. Is that where you're going?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I just wanted to see, even on your stated capacity, how much more volumes could you put out in the market in sheet for in the third quarter versus the second.
componenttext: Well, I just wanted to see, even on your stated capacity, how much more volumes could you put out in the market in sheet for in the third quarter versus the second.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let's see how I can answer that without getting kind of too specific here. How much more can we put out? Listen, we could certainly put out several more millions of tons. Are you talking just for the quarter, just the third quarter?
componenttext: Let's see how I can answer that without getting kind of too specific here. How much more can we put out? Listen, we could certainly put out several more millions of tons. Are you talking just for the quarter, just the third quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just in the quarter. Just on a quarterly basis.
componenttext: Yes, just in the quarter. Just on a quarterly basis.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We could probably improve it about 20%.
componenttext: We could probably improve it about 20%.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: 20%. So with your relative cost advantage with the scrap where it is -- where it's come down to, is it just a question of letting the import supplies dry up in the marketplace?
componenttext: 20%. So with your relative cost advantage with the scrap where it is -- where it's come down to, is it just a question of letting the import supplies dry up in the marketplace?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's been several things. Certainly, that will help. It's also the issue of allowing inventories in warehouses to continue to come down. It's a function that you look at that our business and where is our product going and how those markets performi
componenttext: Well, it's been several things. Certainly, that will help. It's also the issue of allowing inventories in warehouses to continue to come down. It's a function that you look at that our business and where is our product going and how those markets performing. Obviously, we talked about our case participation in the automotive market, and that's a strong market. We talked about nonresidential construction. And clearly, a lot of all of our products, including sheet, will go into nonresidential construction, and we see that picking up. But on the other hand, we also have a lot of products that goes into oil-related products such as OCTG, and that's obviously struggling right now. We don't see that changing for the rest of the year. So we see some of the markets that we sell into our sheet products into is continuing to get better, and we see others that will continue to struggle. But overall, as we look at the third and fourth quarter, what we could put into them, another 20% to 25%. Whether we'll be able to do that will be a function of what happens and how quickly it happens with trade cases, potential trade cases on the hot-rolled and cold rolled products, how quickly that impacts imports coming in. That, of course, will also help drive how quickly the warehouse inventories deplete. But at end of the day, to say that -- I believe that we will be making more and more projects against imports. I feel really good about this pretty recent legislation and the impact it's going to have short term and long term in our business. And so as I look forward for the rest of the year, we do have, as a company, we're heavily weighted on the hot side sometimes, and that's a real advantage. Sometimes, it's not. Right now, that's not advantage. But that will turn around also. So I feel good about where we're going. I feel good about the import situation and the impact it will have the market.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you think about market share, I mean, in the long products part of your business, everyone is subject to the same raw material cost issue, scrap basically in the open market. But in the other half of your business, pretty much in the sheet business,
componenttext: When you think about market share, I mean, in the long products part of your business, everyone is subject to the same raw material cost issue, scrap basically in the open market. But in the other half of your business, pretty much in the sheet business, you have maybe 35% of the market is scrap-based and the other 65% is iron ore-based. And that's where you can get a real advantage in terms of market share pickup. How much market share in the sheet business have you picked -- did you pick up in the second quarter? And then we did talk about what you think you can do the back half of the year?

componenttext: Yes, I would almost have to answer that on a product-by-product basis. I mean, if we look at automotive, we think we'll pick up some market share at automotive. In construction, we feel good about our ability to pick up 2%, 3%, 4% in construction. And as I mentioned earlier, in some of our other markets, we think that will continue to slow.

componenttext: Okay. componenttext: We don't comment on any potential merger or acquisition activity that we're involved in. As a general statement, there's been a long, tough period for the industry. I mean, in the past, based on historical reference points, we see consolidation occur when we've gone through these tough comps. So as a general statement, it's possible, but I'm not going to make any more comments than that.

componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, you said you made a comment that your motto had a pretty strong quarter. Is that a mix piece? Or is that a demand element? componenttext: It was a little bit about, to be honest with you. Demand was up little bit. Also, mix came into play. As we mentioned, we've -- our sections were involved. So mix had something -- we certainly had a role to play in it, but demand was up a little bit also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I add an outlook and a question on you on scrap. Scrap price in U.S., it seems like they've come back down to where they were back in February. When that happened back then, we saw a lot of volume dried up. So question is, is there some theoretical
componenttext: John, I add an outlook and a question on you on scrap. Scrap price in U.S., it seems like they've come back down to where they were back in February. When that happened back then, we saw a lot of volume dried up. So question is, is there some theoretical or numerical floor to where scrap could go given your collection and just costs associated with aggregating it? And then two, how are you guys thinking about the scrap markets in the third quarter? I think one of the [indiscernible] look we think it can't go down lower, and you guys are pretty big and huge. Just want to get your views there, too.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start with that one. I think that going into the -- we're kind of embarrassed on scrap prices going forward. We think that in the third quarter, it will -- we see sideways with some downward pressure. So it [indiscernible] a little bit or sidew
componenttext: Well, I'll start with that one. I think that going into the -- we're kind of embarrassed on scrap prices going forward. We think that in the third quarter, it will -- we see sideways with some downward pressure. So it [indiscernible] a little bit or sideways, but we think probably down a little bit going into the third quarter. In terms of your first question, I don't think there's a numerical floor or such. But certainly, as pricing goes down, again depending upon the time of the deal also, if it was winter and pricing is going down, little harder to go out in the field and start tearing apart that old tractor and scrapping it. But in the summertime, nice weather, pricing goes down a little bit. We don't see any major impact on the flows in our yards, and we don't expect to see it going forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second one, back to, I think, that trade tariffs. I know the industry has got the work with the fields and avenues available. I've heard others described it as trying to hurt a cat when you're trying to deals with imports coming in. Do you
componenttext: Okay. And then second one, back to, I think, that trade tariffs. I know the industry has got the work with the fields and avenues available. I've heard others described it as trying to hurt a cat when you're trying to deals with imports coming in. Do you lock out products from China and other countries? Is there a way to present that Chinese products on finding a home elsewhere in the world? The pricing those local markets and then we end up on getting imports here from another country?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there certainly is a way that's actually happened today. And that is on the countries react much quicker to the flow of imports then we do and they apply the appropriate tariffs and duties in a much quicker manner. So it's not a case of whether or n
componenttext: Well, there certainly is a way that's actually happened today. And that is on the countries react much quicker to the flow of imports then we do and they apply the appropriate tariffs and duties in a much quicker manner. So it's not a case of whether or not this would be product substitution going on and where that ends up going. They have learned the lesson of what's been going on, and they are reacting quicker. The recent legislation is going to give us not quite the same speed, but it is going to improve our ability to deal with that issue by dealing more quickly with each product as it comes up. And ultimately, our there are mechanisms in the law. And if we find us to be a problem that spreads across all products in any one particular country or across different countries, we might be able to take the actions much better perceive our type of action. But we've been successful with it in the past. I'm sure you're familiar with it. It's -- we referred to it as a 201. And should a problem become so obvious that countries are imploring the concept or product solution our country substitution, we would have -- we would not hesitate to go down the path again in the future. Certainly, it's a challenging situation the imports and one that we recognize is probably the largest [indiscernible] is the largest challenge our industry faces. But again, I feel good about the action -- I mentioned this a couple of calls ago, I felt better about what was happening in Washington than I've had in the past 20 years of my steel career. And I feel even better today than I did 2 calls ago.

componenttext: Yes, we believe it -- the iron ore situation we passed right now based on the volumes that we're running at in the month of -- at the end of the quarter, that they would've been cash breakeven then. So clearly, by the end of this year, they will be cash breakeven and cash positive.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I appreciate that. And along the same lines, in addition to the benefits of putting that high-cost iron ore inventory behind you, how much of the unit cost at that DRI facility improve if you tick that utilization slightly higher? Or are you
componenttext: Okay, great. I appreciate that. And along the same lines, in addition to the benefits of putting that high-cost iron ore inventory behind you, how much of the unit cost at that DRI facility improve if you tick that utilization slightly higher? Or are you comfortable with the current utilization rate, which I'm guessing is somewhere just above -- about 85% or so?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we believe that we can get the utilization rate up another 5%, maybe 7% or 8%. And certainly, that's going to have an impact on our cost. But is also a lot of areas that we believe we can improve -- to improve our overall cost structure. One is
componenttext: Yes. Well, we believe that we can get the utilization rate up another 5%, maybe 7% or 8%. And certainly, that's going to have an impact on our cost. But is also a lot of areas that we believe we can improve -- to improve our overall cost structure. One is yield, obviously, and we're focused on that. We have just installed it started up a [indiscernible] which will take some of the waste product from the path and turn into briquettes -- we can put it back into the furnace. We believe that will have a significant impact in the yields going forward. So in addition to getting the utilization up, we're confident we can continue to work down our conversion costs by improving the operation, and that's something Nucor has always been very good at. And I'm sure that our team there would be able to accomplish the same results in that facility.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Great. And just to be clear, what is the current utilization rate of the facility right now at the end of the quarter?

componenttext: This is Jim Frias. We have a very cyclical business, and making predictions about 2016 is very challenging. So our comment would be that's within the range of possibilities, but we'll have to wait and see.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Following up on the trade case questions. In your press release, you noted that -- even if you don't think the trade cases right now are enough to fight off the pressures of global overcapacity, is it really mill closures you think in the end that's going
componenttext: Following up on the trade case questions. In your press release, you noted that -- even if you don't think the trade cases right now are enough to fight off the pressures of global overcapacity, is it really mill closures you think in the end that's going to take that -- that's what's going to take the lift outlook for all the mills over the cycle? And do you see any tangible signs where this overcapacity is beginning to be addressed? Do you think some of this overcapacity is actually in the U.S.? And then last, do you think that this new cascade of global protectionist measures here, the EU, Mexico, India, do you think that's really going to prompt kind of capacity review in places like China that seem to be needed?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I might be the eternal optimist, but I do believe that China beginning to understand that too much of a good thing is not such a good thing. But I believe that they're starting to see that we do have too much capacity. We're hearing a little bit abo
componenttext: Well, I might be the eternal optimist, but I do believe that China beginning to understand that too much of a good thing is not such a good thing. But I believe that they're starting to see that we do have too much capacity. We're hearing a little bit about some potential capacity cutbacks there. It's being driven by economics. It's also being driven by environmental concerns that are very real. So long term, I do think that you're going to see some capacity reduction in China. Right here in the States, it's impossible to say what's going to happen it closes going forward. But in a world where there's overcapacity, sooner or later, there'll be those players who cannot survive. And that will -- that will happen. And the key here is to remember that Nucor has always been a low-cost producers steel and steel products, and that's where we are -- that's our forte. That are really -- that's where we shine. So at the end of the day, there's potential closures here in the United States or somewhere else around the world, this much I can assure you, one of the names of the places closing will not be Nucor. It will be in business. So it's hard for me to comment on who will close or how much will close, but I can assure you is this, and my teammates I can assure this, we won't be one of those that will be closing.
