headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Third Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]Certain statements made this conference will be forward-looking statements involving risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, bel
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Third Quarter of 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]
Certain statements made this conference will be forward-looking statements involving risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate, and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurances that future events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties related to these the forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequentially filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference can speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other execut
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. 
With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other executive vice presidents, Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski and Chad Utermark. 
The entire executive management team would like to thank everyone on our Nucor Harris Steel, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, Newbridge Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for your excellent work taking care of our customers and implementing our company's strategy for long-term, profitable growth. 
Your hard work in these challenging market conditions is paying off. 
First, I will ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to review Nucor's third quarter performance and financial position. Following Jim's comments, I will update you on the execution of our strategy for long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Third quarter 2015 earnings of $0.71 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.50 per diluted share. .Third quarter results included a LIFO credit that was approximately $0.11 per diluted share larger than anticipated in
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Third quarter 2015 earnings of $0.71 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.50 per diluted share. .
Third quarter results included a LIFO credit that was approximately $0.11 per diluted share larger than anticipated in our guidance for the quarter and a $0.03 per diluted share noncash gain related to a correction of deferred tax balances. 
Excluding LIFO and the tax-related gain, the third quarter outperformance resulted from better-than-expected results for the month of September at our Steel Mills and downstream products segments. We are benefiting from the effective execution of Nucor's channel-to-market strategy and our ongoing investments to expand our offerings of value-added products. 
We are successfully expanding into these higher-margin offerings using more demanding and import-resistant applications while, at the same time, maintaining our position as the low cost producer across our product portfolio. 
The third quarter of 2015 performance of our raw materials segment included an operating loss at our new DRI facility in Louisiana of approximately $28 million, which included a $7.7 million net charge related to the write-off of the 2 remaining storage at the facility. That compared with the second quarter operating loss of about $20 million, which included the benefit of the vendor product warranty payment of approximately $10 million. 
As expected, Nucor Steel Louisiana has now consumed the remaining higher cost iron ore inventory acquired in 2014. In addition to continuing to produce DRI at world-class quality levels, our Louisiana team has realized significant improvements in yield, facility uptime and conversion costs. 
Nucor's DRI production capability in Louisiana and Trinidad puts our company in an unrivaled position of flexibility and optimizing our raw material costs through the cycle. 
A quick comment of our tax rate to adjust for the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. Excluding profits belonging to our business partners and the $10.2 million noncash gain for correction of deferred tax balances, the effective tax rate was approximately 29% for the third quarter. 
Nucor continued to generate very robust operating cash flow in extremely challenging steel market conditions. With a highly variable and low-cost structure, we benefit from significant reductions in working capital during downturns. That was the case again in the first 9 months of 2015 with cash provided by operations of approximately $1.8 billion, a dramatic increase from the year-ago period's operating cash flow of $926 million. Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 36% at the close of the third quarter. Cash and short-term investments totaled approximately $2 billion, which compares with total debt outstanding of $4.4 billion. Our next significant debt maturity is not until December 2017. 
Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until August of 2018. 
Nucor's the only North American steel producer to hold an investment-grade credit rating. 
Capital expenditures totaled $269 million for the first 9 months of 2015. We estimate full year 2015 capital spending will be approximately $400 million. Most of our recent larger scale organic investments have been completed or are nearing completion. 
Depreciation and amortization for 2015 is expected to total about $700 million. 
In September, Nucor's Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to $900 million of our company's common stock. This replaced a repurchase program that had been in place since 2007. The timing and amount of repurchases will depend on market conditions, share price, applicable legal requirements and other factors. The Nucor team places the highest priority on making sound capital allocation decisions that continue our long-term history of being effective stewards of our shareholders' investments. 
Earnings in the fourth quarter of 2015 are expected to decrease compared to the third quarter of 2015 due to continued deterioration in global steel markets. A slowing economy in China is causing further global overcapacity and resulting in significant levels of imports into the domestic market. The performance of our downstream product segment is expected to decrease due to typical fourth quarter seasonality. 
We expect slightly lower performance in the raw materials segment due to lower scrap and metallic commodity prices. 
We are encouraged by the ongoing gradual improvement in nonresidential construction markets and the strength in the automotive market. We are confident in Nucor's significant competitive advantages and highly adaptable business model will allow our team to continue to execute our proven strategies for delivering profitable, long-term growth. We do appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Typical words used to describe current steel market conditions range from bleak to dismal. However, those words, in no way, describe the attitude and outlook of the Nucor team. Even better, those words also do not describe the performance of
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Typical words used to describe current steel market conditions range from bleak to dismal. However, those words, in no way, describe the attitude and outlook of the Nucor team. Even better, those words also do not describe the performance of any of my teammates in the third quarter's extremely challenging environment. 
At Nucor, we remain optimistic, determined and focused. Nucor's long-term success has always been driven by our team's unrelenting focus on a simple strategy. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength to gain profitable market share in our core businesses of steel and steel products. In short, we work on what's under our control. Anchoring this strategy and its execution is Nucor's business model. Its strength and adaptability is highlighted by a number of powerful building blocks. They include: our culture, our robust balance sheet and cash flow generation, our low and highly variable cost structure, our flexibility and reliable production capabilities, our product diversity and our leadership positions that we hold in many of the markets we serve. Put together, these competitive strengths provide Nucor with a powerful platform for delivering value to our customers. 
Challenging market conditions, as we face currently, on serve to increase the opportunities to add value and grow our long-term relationships with our customers. 
What we call Nucor's 5 drivers to profitable growth highlight where we are focusing our energies to build long-term earnings power and provide our shareholders with attractive returns on their valuable capital. They are: one, enhance our position as a low-cost producer: two, achieve a market leadership position in every product line in our portfolio; three, move up the value chain by expanding our capabilities to produce higher-quality, more import-resistant products; four, expand our downstream channels to market to increase our steel mills' base buying load, especially in weak markets; and five, achieve commercial excellence to complement our traditional operational strength. 
Our third quarter performance provides strong evidence that our strategy of investing through the downturn is already paying off. Rather than being stuck in a defensive mode fighting to survive, the Nucor team is on the offensive and growing stronger. The examples are numerous. Let me review a few of them for you. 
Through the first 9 months of 2015, our rebar and merchant bar mills delivered year-over-year earnings improvement despite the challenges of high imports and less-than-robust capacity utilization rates. The keys to their success are clear. They have built market leadership positions. Equally important, they have established strong channels to market through Nucor's downstream joists, decking, rebar fabrication, cold finish bar and fastener businesses by providing our steel mills the opportunity to earn a base level of volume, our downstream vertical integration into value-added steel products significantly enhances that through the cycle profitability and flexibility of Nucor's core steelmaking business. Additionally, the downstream businesses are attractive profit generators for Nucor as well. All 3 major fabricated construction products, joist and decking, fabricated rebar and metal buildings, achieved very strong profit growth year-over-year in the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2015. 
I'm pleased to report that our Vulcraft vertical joist and decking group that a single-month profitability record in September. More importantly, both our Vulcraft Verco group and our metal buildings group achieved record performance for the third quarter of 2015. The improved results of our fabricated construction products group is particularly impressive when you consider the state of the overall construction market. 
Forecasted U.S. nonresidential construction activity for 2015, as measured by square footage, represents only about 60% of  2007's peak activity level. So there's plenty of room for additional growth. 
I would like to congratulate and thank our teammates for their hard work reducing costs and providing world-class quality products and services to our customers. 
Our B mills also delivered attractive year-to-date earnings growth while placing high import levels and low-mill capacity utilization. Nucor's structural steel group's success is driven by a potent combination of its market leadership position; strong channels to market throughout our independent, wide-flange beam fabricated partners; our Skyline Steel piling distribution business; and new product introductions that continue to move us up the value chain. 
After completing last year's $115 million [ph] sheet piling product expansion project, our Nucor-Yamato will is now enjoying strong marketplace success with its new wider piling sections. These value-added products are lighter and stronger, covering more area at a lower installed cost. Our Nucor-Yamato team is aggressively going after this market, which currently is largely supplied by imports. 
Our goal over the next several years is to grow our wider piling section's annual volume to 100,000 tons, with these value-added tons generating above-average profitability. 
Last month, Nucor-Yamato announced another project to expand its value-added offerings. A $75 million quench and self-tempering process will be installed, with commissioning expected during the second half of 2016. This will give Nucor-Yamato the capability to produce A913 structural sections, with a high-strength, low-alloy great chemistry that provides excellent weldability while achieving good toughness even at low temperatures. Common applications include gravity columns for high-rise buildings, long-span trusses for stadiums and convention centers and for all projects where seismic design is a critical factor. These A913 beams allow the use of lighter footweights, which reduces the weight and cost for the builder. That makes steel even more competitive versus concrete and wood. 
The low-alloy great chemistry also enhances our position as a low-cost producer of beams. As the sole North American supplier of high-strength, low-alloy beams, Nucor Yamato will further enhance its market leadership position in wide-flange beams. 
Nucor's focus on our drivers to profitable growth and resulting strategic investments are paying big dividends in our other businesses. This is particularly evident in the markets that are under the greatest pressure from the flood of imports and other challenges. Our Berkeley County, South Carolina sheet mill achieved very solid third quarter and year-to-date profitability in what can only be described as horrific flat-rolled market conditions. The Berkeley team is capitalizing on its investments in degassing, combined with upgrades last year to its caster and hot mill. The mill's performance is being driven by its very diverse product mix, technical capabilities and commitment to commercial excellence. As we have discussed on previous calls, Berkeley now has the lightest hot-rolled gauge capability of any sheet mill in the southern U.S. market and with a finished steel capability of up to 74 inches. 
New products from the wide-light monetization are allowing us to gain new business in a range of end-use markets, including metal buildings, rail cars, oil heaters, automotive, heavy equipment and water transmission pipe. 
Despite severe pressure from imports and demand weakness in several key end-use markets, Nucor's engineered bar mills remain profitable. We are moving aggressively to utilize our recently expanded range of production and inspection capabilities to grow profitable market share in the SBQ and wire rod markets. 
Our Memphis mill was recently awarded Automotive Business that is a direct result of its quality inspection investments made since 2012. This week, Memphis announced another improvement, the very cost-effective acquisition of a continuous quench in Temple line, with a separate and kneeling furnace, capable of processing bar products from 2.5 inches to 11 inches in diameter. The addition of heat-treating capabilities will enable Memphis to grow in a number of markets, including energy, heavy equipment, service centers and automotive. 
The automotive market continues to be an attractive growth opportunity for Nucor. Nucor's shipping rate into the automotive market increased by 20% in 2015 versus 2014 to a 1.4 million ton per year rate. Particularly encouraging is the volume of business that Nucor is being awarded on future automotive platforms. The automotive companies are more and more appreciating the value of Nucor's reliability, sustainability and our financial strength. Our portfolio of light-weighting advanced, high-strength steels is also attracting a lot of interest. We remain optimistic about reaching our 2 million tons annual goal in the next few years. 
Finally, our Darlington, South Carolina facilities wire rod rolling mill continues to grow Nucor's market share in the wire rod market. Year-to-date, rod shipments through the first 9 months are up 11% compared to 2014. Darlington's wire rod growth is also allowing us to more efficiently utilize capacity at our other bar mills producing merchant bar and rebar products. 
Since I have mentioned several times the challenging market conditions faced by all of our businesses, I will share my thoughts on what is, by far, the biggest factor driving the weakness. 
Illegally traded imports continue to have a significant impact on the U.S. steel industry. The underlying issue is global steelmaking overcapacity resulting from the trade-distorting practices of some governments. Steel imports into the U.S. market remained at historically high levels. The import levels are depressing to capacity utilization rates of the U.S. steel producers and continue to account for 1/3 of the U.S. market. In the first 8 months of this year, China's global steel exports serves 27% to 72 million tons. They are on track to exceed 100 million tons, which is greater than the total U.S. steel production last year. 
Steel products from China are flooding into markets around the world, creating a domino effect as countries look for markets for their steel products. The massive increase in China's steel exports are provoking a wave of trade actions across the globe, including Europe, South Africa, Mexico and India, as steel producers fight against illegally subsidized steel imports being dumped into their markets. 
As these nations continue to successfully protect their markets from illegally traded and subsidized  Chinese steel products, more of those products are being dumped into our market. Recent decisions in several trade cases have been positive for the U.S. industry. The International Trade Commission has made preliminary determinations of injury in the cold-rolled, hot-rolled and corrosion-resistant sheet steel trade cases, allowing the investigation in all 3 cases to proceed. Nucor will continue to assess market conditions in other product areas and aggressively pursue cases when appropriate. 
Our fight against illegally traded steel imports is essential to meeting our responsibility to being effective steward of our shareholders' valuable capital. These are challenging times, but for a company such as Nucor, one that is in a unique position of strength, these are also times for opportunistic action. And that is exactly what I see throughout Nucor, the right people, focusing their unrivaled energy level and sense of urgency to achieving our goal of profitable growth. 
I have never been more confident that Nucor's best years are still ahead of us. 
Thank you for your interest in Nucor. We would now be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you kind of beat my number on pricing alone. Actually, the volume number's a little bit weak. So it's kind of led me to believe that perhaps you're taking a pretty disciplined approach about which steel you actually want to sell into the market at
componenttext: I think you kind of beat my number on pricing alone. Actually, the volume number's a little bit weak. So it's kind of led me to believe that perhaps you're taking a pretty disciplined approach about which steel you actually want to sell into the market at this point. And perhaps you may be walking away from the lower-value sales that are head-to-head with imports. Just kind of want to confirm that and get a sense of how about you think about selling into a weak market like this and what that's doing to your mix. And then how does that kind of play into how you see operating rates in the fourth quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start by saying you hit the nail on the head with your analysis. We mentioned in my earlier comments that a key part of our strategic plan is to continue to grow market share in the higher-quality, higher-margin, more profitable products, and that'
componenttext: Let me start by saying you hit the nail on the head with your analysis. We mentioned in my earlier comments that a key part of our strategic plan is to continue to grow market share in the higher-quality, higher-margin, more profitable products, and that's exactly what we've been doing. So yes, that had some impact on our total output. The higher-quality products, although they are more profitable, do tend to run slower on our mills. So that has some impact upon the amount of tons that we ship. But you're spot on. We are looking hard at those products that we believe bring higher margins, higher profits to our company and also more import-resistant. Given the overcapacity in the world today, we believe that, that's an important element of our long-term strategy.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe just a question on trade. I've heard a couple of conflicting views on how the process works, and I just wanted to try to clarify this. But obviously, over the past couple of months, in particular, we've really seen seaborne steel prices a
componenttext: Great. And maybe just a question on trade. I've heard a couple of conflicting views on how the process works, and I just wanted to try to clarify this. But obviously, over the past couple of months, in particular, we've really seen seaborne steel prices absolutely get crushed. And clearly, that data would be good to have in these trade cases as far as proving dumping. Is there an opportunity for the meals to go back and add some of these data before the final rulings would come out at some point next year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There absolutely is. In fact, in some cases, as is the case with rebar, we were not at all happy with the termination on the tariff that was applying-ed to the product surging into our country from Turkey. And we consider solely going back and appealing t
componenttext: There absolutely is. In fact, in some cases, as is the case with rebar, we were not at all happy with the termination on the tariff that was applying-ed to the product surging into our country from Turkey. And we consider solely going back and appealing that decision. And obviously, we will use the pricing data that you just mentioned as a strong component in that appeal. So yes, we can use that information that's out there today, and we will use it effectively. And I would just add to that, that we spoke a little bit in the past about the recently passed legislation that strengthens the trade remedies that are available to us and, frankly, giving us more effective tools for fighting against this illegally traded products. And we're really pleased with the way that, that came out. We're very appreciative to the administration and to Congress for making that happen. And those new regulations, those new guidelines will be applied to the trade cases that are, in effect, going into effect now. The corrosion-resistant, the hot-rolled and the cold-rolled will all be impacted by the new trade remedies that are currently in effect. And as a result, we're optimistic as to the outcome of this. We think we have very strong cases, and we expect to have very positive results.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Just to clarify that one more time. Sorry if I'm being a little bit dense here. But the data that's coming up to date, would you have had to wait to appeal if you wanted to include that so after the trade case is finalized? Or can you actually get
componenttext: Great. Just to clarify that one more time. Sorry if I'm being a little bit dense here. But the data that's coming up to date, would you have had to wait to appeal if you wanted to include that so after the trade case is finalized? Or can you actually get that in may be between the preliminary and the final ruling a little bit sooner?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me be clear. I might have confused the issue there for a minute. I was speaking in the case of rebar where there was a determination. We'll be able to use that data as we go back into the appeal. In the cases of cold-rolled and hot-rolled and corrosio
componenttext: Let me be clear. I might have confused the issue there for a minute. I was speaking in the case of rebar where there was a determination. We'll be able to use that data as we go back into the appeal. In the cases of cold-rolled and hot-rolled and corrosion resistance, we will be able to use that pricing data in these current cases. We will not have to wait for a determination and then use it in the field. They can be entered in to the case as we press it forward.

componenttext: Maybe just a follow up on the mix question there. So in particular, I noticed cold finished was fairly low relative to where you've been at in Q3 in past years. And same was play. Just wondering if you can share any color on that. Is that specifically choosing not to compete on price? Or is there demand weakness?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: In those 2 instances you just gave, it's more of a case of the demand is, frankly, still pretty good. Relative to last year, demand across all of our products is about consistent, maybe down 2% or 3%. The issue that was probably went particularly on plate
componenttext: In those 2 instances you just gave, it's more of a case of the demand is, frankly, still pretty good. Relative to last year, demand across all of our products is about consistent, maybe down 2% or 3%. The issue that was probably went particularly on plate is the massive amount of illegally traded, unfairly traded products coming in from many countries, particularly Russia is one that I would mention in particular. So it's an issue of excessive supply as a result of imports. There is a little bit demand decrease when you look at agriculture and construction using heavy plate. So there's a little bit of a demand impact, but the real issue on plate, without a doubt, is the supply and the oversupply as a result of the imports.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: And then just a follow-up on the structural pricing. That was another area I noticed had come down a bit faster in Q3. How are you seeing structural pricing going forward? Is it sliding? Or do you think you can -- you could stabilize it?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: We think structural pricing going forward will be fairly stable.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'm wondering, are there any customers, any buyers from whom you received orders who may be the first time in a while who are shifting away from imported steel in anticipation of the effect of trade cases? On the flip side, are there any buyers out the
componenttext: So I'm wondering, are there any customers, any buyers from whom you received orders who may be the first time in a while who are shifting away from imported steel in anticipation of the effect of trade cases? On the flip side, are there any buyers out there that told you, "You know, right now, we are good. Inventories are okay. I'm seeing the step down in scrap prices and that kind of see the Shake Out coming into the new year?"

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you've asked 2 questions, and the answer to both of them, frankly, is yes. We are seeing customers coming back to us who recognizing that right now, their inventories are a little bit bloated. So we don't see the point in right now with new orders.
componenttext: Well, you've asked 2 questions, and the answer to both of them, frankly, is yes. We are seeing customers coming back to us who recognizing that right now, their inventories are a little bit bloated. So we don't see the point in right now with new orders. But we are hearing from them that because of the trade cases and, frankly, because of oil pricing has become much more competitive relative to imported pricing, that they have not placed the orders for imports to the same level that they have in the past. And as you know, when you're talking about import orders, there's about a 2 to 3 months, maybe 4 months sometimes, depending upon the product, delay or lag time between when the order was placed and when the product arrives. So many of our service center customers, in particular, are recognizing that the orders that they placed 2, 3, 4 months ago now do not nearly as attractive. And unfortunately, they're on the water, they're on the way and they can't be canceled. So we're going to see this issue of heavy inventories continue for a little bit of time. But ultimately, we do believe that because when we're more competitive today and because they are seeing some other issues with lead times from the imported products, we'll be able to regain that business. We see our customers coming back to us from the imports. The other comment that I'll make, just in general, you asked about other customers coming back to us. We'll also see many new customers approaching us because they see Nucor as a company with a very strong financial position and sustainable. We know they're going to be here for a long term, and there's some other companies that might be able challenged, particularly of this challenging time continues for another quarter or 2. So the answer to your question is yes, and yes to 2 question, yes.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. Let me follow up with a really quickly just saying, the details of organic products to the capacity development that you're doing, that's great. How are you thinking about the use of available capital in terms of M&A? Is there any sense of,
componenttext: Very helpful. Let me follow up with a really quickly just saying, the details of organic products to the capacity development that you're doing, that's great. How are you thinking about the use of available capital in terms of M&A? Is there any sense of, look, we're in strong financial shape, especially relative to the group. We're expecting the bottom to come in sooner than later. Let's get active. Let's sign other assets. Let's tuck in some more downstream facilities. Is that --  what's your thinking there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to answer that in a more general sense and talk about how we view what we're doing with our cash. We have been a strong cash generator. This has been a very good year in terms of cash generation from operations. And certainly, acquisitions
componenttext: Well, I'm going to answer that in a more general sense and talk about how we view what we're doing with our cash. We have been a strong cash generator. This has been a very good year in terms of cash generation from operations. And certainly, acquisitions would be one thing that we will look at. But in a more general sense, when I think about that the deployment of our cash going forward, our first priority will always be aggressive growth, profitable growth in our company. And that can be done several ways. Organic growth has been, for us, one of the ways that we get the loss of returns with the investments that we've made. And you've heard us to us today as in the past conference calls, numerous projects in which we are growing our company profitably through organic investments in our existing operations. Frankly, acquisitions is another way that we are deploying our cash to accomplish profitable growth. Skyline would be an example of that, for the reason, we were reasonable that would be Gallatin, our Gallatin acquisition. So yes, we're looking at that. It's a way to not only grow our volumes, but to grow our customer base and grow the breadth of our products. And that's something that's very important as we look at potential targets out there. And I take this opportunity to just remind you of one other way that we can grow our company through investments, and that's we got a pretty good track record of growing through greenfield expansion. And I know that there's a lot of overcapacity, and everybody is lifting their eyebrows when I say that But we are confident looking for unique market opportunities, product niches in which we can grow through greenfield expansion.

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Timna Tanners from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I also want to follow up, if I could, on the [indiscernible] because it is the highest that you've had since 2009, and that would may be honkering down. So I guess I just want to know, is that preparing for restocking? Does the message about your reaut
componenttext: So I also want to follow up, if I could, on the [indiscernible] because it is the highest that you've had since 2009, and that would may be honkering down. So I guess I just want to know, is that preparing for restocking? Does the message about your reauthorized buyback programs send a signal? Or just -- I know there's a lot of uses of this cash. Just wondered his ability even for you so I just wondered if you could provide any priorities of how you're thinking about using them, if you could.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I've mentioned that the #1 priority is to profitably grow our company, and that will always be our first priority. In terms of building up a large cash reserve on our war chest, how are we looking at that, I don't think that we're looking at it as a
componenttext: Well, I've mentioned that the #1 priority is to profitably grow our company, and that will always be our first priority. In terms of building up a large cash reserve on our war chest, how are we looking at that, I don't think that we're looking at it as a need to be able to grow our inventories, working capital as the business gets better. That's really -- that is not what is driving it. The opportunity for opportunistic buys as we go forward, again, as this challenging time extends out, there might be opportunities, as we've done in the past, to pick up some very good assets at a very good price. One of our strategies has always been to grow our company during the downturns when assets are less expensive. So we think that that's currently happening as we go forward. We think this can be more assets available at the prices. And we want to make sure that we're prepared to capitalize on those opportunities. So we have that, and it's one of the reasons that we're making sure that we're preserving our cash. Now to your questions about dividends  and buyback programs, I'll make just a couple of comments. First of all, as you know, we paid a very healthy dividend today, and we've proven in the past that one-off profit levels as such, that we can pay out a supplemental dividend without adversely affecting our ability to aggressively grow and profitably grow our company. We'll do it. Right now, that's not the case. And in terms of the buyback, what we did was we rest our Board to authorize a buyback program. That was, frankly, in place, so really just refreshing a program that had already been authorized and been on the books for many years. We did that. We want to be prepared for a situation where it might be limited profitable growth opportunities that do not provide a return, a large enough return that would without ways that we're purchasing of our stock. In other words, when you take a look at the opportunities in front of us. We want to make sure that the return that we gain from those acquisitions, those investments surpass what we would gain for our shareholders by repurchasing the scraps, the stock. If that's not the case, we want to be ready. If that situation should come up suddenly, we want to be ready. One thing about this industry, Timna, as you know, it changes. And when a change occurs, it occurs rapidly. And we made this move just so that we're ready for that eventuality.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. One of the things that you have to remember about our company, we have such a broad portfolio of businesses, such a large portfolio, upstream, some core businesses, downstream. If you look at our various business, we have about 12 businesses that pr
componenttext: Okay. One of the things that you have to remember about our company, we have such a broad portfolio of businesses, such a large portfolio, upstream, some core businesses, downstream. If you look at our various business, we have about 12 businesses that provide an opportunity, which we can invest. That's a large number of opportunities. And it spans a very broad spectrum of opportunities. So as I look at the situation going forward, we can see opportunities, both upstream, core business and downstream, we want to make sure that we're ready. We think they're going to become available as this struggle to get through this challenging time. And we want to be positioned to take advantage of that, to capitalize on that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to ask, if I could, about the --  my second question will be about the raw materials segment. And I cringe to ask this, but I know that you're probably not delayed to be reporting losses in the segment. And I know that DRI was looking a lot
componenttext: Okay. I wanted to ask, if I could, about the --  my second question will be about the raw materials segment. And I cringe to ask this, but I know that you're probably not delayed to be reporting losses in the segment. And I know that DRI was looking a lot better positioned when met coal prices were much higher. But what are you thinking about doing to 6 [indiscernible]? Or is it just strategic and you're okay with loss there for now?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said many times that DRI investment is investment for the long term. And that we recognize, we recognize that from the beginning that it's going to be pricing situations in raw materials in which the DRI investment is going to be a single and
componenttext: Well, as we said many times that DRI investment is investment for the long term. And that we recognize, we recognize that from the beginning that it's going to be pricing situations in raw materials in which the DRI investment is going to be a single and times when it's going to be a home run and times when it's going to be a grand slam. But the other point that I would make is that we always look at our investments for the long term. And when you look at the macro impact reasons for making the investments, the fact that manufacturing is leaving the country and with its prime scrap, when you look at long  term, we still believe that availability in the pricing for natural gas will be much more attractive than that for coking coal. When you look at the improvement in the efficiency of automotive blanking, which results in less prime scrap availability, even in periods when the automotive market is very strong, for all of these reasons, as we look long term, we believe that having the ability to produce a low-residual scrap substitute product for Nucor is going to be a very good investment. And if I may, Timna, I let you ask the second question maybe you could make me let me make a second statement about this response. And that's one thing that we -- I don't know that we emphasize enough when we talk about the DRI project and what it does for us. And that gives us -- it's that it gives us tremendous flexibility in our selection of the material used for our furnaces. And by using that flexibility, we're able to impact other scrap, well, other iron-muted products, and that's been very beneficial to us. I mean, you've seen the impact of that a couple of months ago when we saw such a tremendous drop in scrap. We'd also suggest to you that whenever we put in or take out 4 million tons of a scrap substitute product, it's going to have an impact on other iron-muted products. It's just going to have an impact. So it gives us tremendous flexibility and the ability to better utilize our scrap mix to enhance our low-cost position as the steel supplier.

componenttext: I had a question about the bar volumes that we saw decline sequentially, 8% quarter-on-quarter, even exceeding that of sheet. Can you give some color as to what's happening in bars? Obviously, we know that energy has been weak, but are there any other end markets that bars will be going into that would account for that kind of sequential weakness?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, you hit the nail on the head. Certainly, energy in which a lot of our special bar quality products going to energy, that's taking a tremendous hit. We mentioned earlier, agriculture, that's been way down, and of course, we have a lot of produ
componenttext: Well, again, you hit the nail on the head. Certainly, energy in which a lot of our special bar quality products going to energy, that's taking a tremendous hit. We mentioned earlier, agriculture, that's been way down, and of course, we have a lot of product, all products going into agriculture. So that's another area where we've seen a declining market. And finally, I would say, heavy equipment. And heavy equipment market is down. And once again, I'm going to go back to my favorite subject, and that's unfairly traded imports because when you look at particularly rebar, the unfairly traded rebar into this country over the last year has been -- it's just totally unacceptable. And it's had a tremendous impact upon all volume and our profitability in that area, ballparks.

componenttextpreview: $50 to $70. And when you have that kind of a scrap price drop, it certainly has an impact on our scrap operations. So yes, we've seen improvement in our DRI performance and the performance of our DRI plant. But the raw material has a result of our scrap o
componenttext: $50 to $70. And when you have that kind of a scrap price drop, it certainly has an impact on our scrap operations. So yes, we've seen improvement in our DRI performance and the performance of our DRI plant. But the raw material has a result of our scrap operations.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And the last question again on trade. Are there any similarities between now and back at the end of 2001 in the Chinese hot-rolled case where Chinese [indiscernible] marked out of hot-rolled since then with a 90% tariff?
componenttext: Right. And the last question again on trade. Are there any similarities between now and back at the end of 2001 in the Chinese hot-rolled case where Chinese [indiscernible] marked out of hot-rolled since then with a 90% tariff?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are some similarities. And actually, the way that it differs is that the amount of hot-rolled and all steel products that China is exporting today compared to where it was back then is -- has increased by a magnitude of, I don't know, 10%, 20%, 30%
componenttext: There are some similarities. And actually, the way that it differs is that the amount of hot-rolled and all steel products that China is exporting today compared to where it was back then is -- has increased by a magnitude of, I don't know, 10%, 20%, 30% at times. It's just unbelievable. But they're talking about exporting. I think the number year-to-date that's coming out in China somewhere around 72 million tons year-to-date. It's expected to go up to over 100 million tons this year. Bearing in mind that the entire U.S. market is 100 million tons, that's a ridiculous amount to be exported out of one country. And it's a direct consequence of their -- of that building tremendous amount of overcapacity in China. So yes, there's some similarities in the sense that they're flooding the market today. They flooded the market then. And will be aggressive in pursuing cases against them today as we were back in 2000.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Lane with MorningStar.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, could you provide some color as to the integration of Nucor Steel Gallatin, given it was about a year ago, around this date, that the acquisition was completed? Has the contribution of Gallatin fallen in line with your expectations? And then also i
componenttext: First, could you provide some color as to the integration of Nucor Steel Gallatin, given it was about a year ago, around this date, that the acquisition was completed? Has the contribution of Gallatin fallen in line with your expectations? And then also in terms of virgin iron units at Gallatin, are those being supplied via imported material or via DRI produced in-house?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I have say no to the first part of your question. The integration is not going as we expected it to go. Frankly, it's going much, much better. And we view, going into that into the acquisition that we had a lot of similarities of our c
componenttext: Well, first of all, I have say no to the first part of your question. The integration is not going as we expected it to go. Frankly, it's going much, much better. And we view, going into that into the acquisition that we had a lot of similarities of our culture. And clearly, cultural compatibility is very high on our list of targets that we look to acquire. And all I can say, and I hope our teams in Gallatin are listening, those guys have done a great job coming up to speed. They are doing a great job with integrating, assimilating into the Nucor culture. We share a lot of similar cultural traits. And in one area, frankly, and I want to thank them for this, in one area, they helped us get a whole lot better. And that was in the area of safety. Safety performance before the acquisition was outstanding. The commitment to working safe is phenomenal. And the way they won their safety programs is phenomenal. We've learned quite a bit from them. So despite the fact that Gallatin is operating today in an extremely tough market, the energy, which is a big product coming out of Gallatin, as you know, has been really, really challenged. But our teammates are doing what we always do on Nucor, and that is finding new ways, new products. One example would be that they are working hard to qualify for automotive products, and we expect them to be successful in that attempt. And all I can say is that it is, without a doubt, going much better than we anticipated. And one other comment your question about where are they getting their materials from, obviously, on the scrap side, there's a lot of synergies with our operations right up the road. We have metals and scrap substitute today. They are taking scrap substitutes in. We are working to modify the plants so that can accept DRI out of our Louisiana plant. We expect that to be up in line sometime the end of next year, first part of 2017, at DRI.

componenttext: Well, let me start off by saying that this is the second time in your one question where you've made me smile, question about Gallatin made me smile about how well that's gone. And I'm smiling now because I can tell you, we have completely digested the higher-cost iron ore. We work our way completely through that. And so the second part of your question was of the $28 million loss in the quarter. First of all, I would suggest that the number's actually closer to $20 million because of that impact. Jimmy want to jump in on the impact of the $7 million?

componenttext: Yes, we had some raw material iron ore and storage that we made a decision that we were not going to continue to use. And so we had the write-down just under $8 million. But John, I think his question is of the $20 million loss, how much is driven by higher costs, iron ore? I think we have that number in our fingertips.

componenttextpreview: No but we don't have that number.
componenttext: No but we don't have that number.

componenttext: Finishing [indiscernible] a little trade-off and not anything notable.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And one other thing, another reason why I'm smiling, to be honest with you, is our Louisiana plant was cash positive in the last 2 months. And so that's a significant improvement. Now they will continue to be challenged, given the current pricing of
componenttext: Yes. And one other thing, another reason why I'm smiling, to be honest with you, is our Louisiana plant was cash positive in the last 2 months. And so that's a significant improvement. Now they will continue to be challenged, given the current pricing of raw materials in general. That's going to be a challenging operation for a while. As I said earlier, we don't expect it to be a grand slam in this pricing environment. But long term, we have great deal of confidence that it was a good investment and will pay large dividends over the long run.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: A question on the automotive business. And just want to understand where we are in terms of kind of the absolute tonnage penetration. And maybe if you could give us a breakout of products within that number, whether it be cold-finished bar, hot band SBQ, cold-rolled, just kind of a general thought process here and then how you're looking to go that market going forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's good question. It's an area that we're very, very proud of the way that we've been able to grow that business. When you ask about specific shipment rates in 2015, we are on track to ship at a rate of about 1.4 million tons a year, and that's a
componenttext: Yes, that's good question. It's an area that we're very, very proud of the way that we've been able to grow that business. When you ask about specific shipment rates in 2015, we are on track to ship at a rate of about 1.4 million tons a year, and that's about a 20% improvement over where we were the last year. In terms of a breakdown between sheet and cold-finished, today, about 85% of approximately in 2 automotive are in sheet products, and 15% coming out of some form of SBQ or cold finish. And in terms of where we want to go, the sky's the limit ultimately. But over the next 2 or 3 years, we are confident that we will be able to grow that business to a rate of about 2 million tons of shipments per year going into automotive.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. 2 million [ph] is what you said, okay. I appreciate that. And then...
componenttext: Okay. 2 million [ph] is what you said, okay. I appreciate that. And then...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, over the next 2 to 3 years. Beyond that, we will continue to grow in that market as we will continue to grow in all high-quality, higher-valued and more import-resistant products.
componenttext: Okay, over the next 2 to 3 years. Beyond that, we will continue to grow in that market as we will continue to grow in all high-quality, higher-valued and more import-resistant products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of what your feelers are out there on nonresidential construction and what those are telling you. What's the read at this point in time just noticing the fabrication? I think volumes were down a little bit year-on-year. Any se
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of what your feelers are out there on nonresidential construction and what those are telling you. What's the read at this point in time just noticing the fabrication? I think volumes were down a little bit year-on-year. Any sense of why that's the case? Just trying to get a better feel for your view of nonres and what your indicators are telling you right now.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would start off by saying that we do think that the rate of growth in nonresidential construction, as we measured in square footage, has slowed. At the beginning of the year, we were anticipating somewhere about an 8% or 9% growth over the cost of
componenttext: Well, I would start off by saying that we do think that the rate of growth in nonresidential construction, as we measured in square footage, has slowed. At the beginning of the year, we were anticipating somewhere about an 8% or 9% growth over the cost of the year. Today, we would say that, that number is probably closer to 5% or 6% today. So we do see the rate of increase, the rate of growth slowing as the year has progressed. Now when I look at all business in particular, Nucor's business in our downstream businesses, which frankly go into the nonresidential construction, we're feeling pretty good about our backlogs. Our backlog today in all 3 of our downstream businesses, bull crap, Velcro, drilling systems and Harris, our backlogs are the largest they've been, strongest they have been in a 10-year period. And when you couple that with the profitability that we talked about earlier, we've had a very good quarter for our downstream businesses. Although we see the rate of improvement slowing, we still feel pretty good about our downstream businesses and their ability to compete in the construction markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the shipments, John, was that year-over-year comparisons a bit negative because maybe there were some overbond in Q1 and you need a quarter to level that out? Because your backlog is pretty strong from what you're saying right now.
componenttext: In terms of the shipments, John, was that year-over-year comparisons a bit negative because maybe there were some overbond in Q1 and you need a quarter to level that out? Because your backlog is pretty strong from what you're saying right now.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's hard to take a look at -- that's a business that those progress are long-term projects some of them spanning several years. So as you look at the length of time, it becomes cyclical, the order entry rate become cyclical, the shipping rates have
componenttext: Yes, it's hard to take a look at -- that's a business that those progress are long-term projects some of them spanning several years. So as you look at the length of time, it becomes cyclical, the order entry rate become cyclical, the shipping rates have become cyclical. So it's hard to look at any one particular quarter and compared to another particular period of time. You got to really look at the overall order entry rate and the backlog. And that's what we use to track how we see the business performing.

componenttext: Okay. And then I have one high-level political/philosophical question, and then I'll jump off. And then in terms of the TPP, are you concerned if that's -- are you concerned if that measure is passed without any further safeguards like FX manipulation?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that one, but I would like to address both of them. We are absolutely concerned about TPP passing in its present form. Now remember, we're all -- all of us have not yet gotten a chance to look at the complete documents. I'm not going to sa
componenttext: I'll start with that one, but I would like to address both of them. We are absolutely concerned about TPP passing in its present form. Now remember, we're all -- all of us have not yet gotten a chance to look at the complete documents. I'm not going to say whether or not we would struggle with it until we have an opportunity to read and to study the entire document, which we have not had at this time. That said, I will say that we are extremely, extremely disappointed that it's not -- that currency manipulation is not all strongly baked into that agreement. At the end of the day, you can have all kinds of trade agreements. And if a country manipulates its currency, it's guaranteed to have an unfair trade advantage. And so we have -- what we are insisting upon with TPP is that it does as it's promising to do, and that is to provide a more level playing field on which we can compete. We, at Nucor, are absolutely convinced that if we were given a level playing field to compete upon, we would compete successfully against any company or any country in the world. So we're taking a hard look at TPP before we come out with a definitive statement, but you are absolutely correct in saying that currency manipulation, not being a part of that agreement, makes us who really struggle about the impact it will have on our company, the impact it will have on our industry, the impact it'll have on manufacturing in the United States and the impact, most importantly, that it will have upon middle-class Americans working hard to make a living and make a better for themselves and their family. So you got a little philosophical, so did I, okay? Now to infrastructure. Once again, I have to say that I'm disappointed in the administration. And frankly, Congress is not taking advantage of, what I consider, a great opportunity. Right now, steel costs are down, but a time to focus on rebuilding our infrastructure, okay? Energy, okay? How important is energy going forward in the manufacturing world for our country, frankly? What a great time to be able to rebuild our energy infrastructure, our power grids. And frankly, with the price of oil where it is today and the resulting price of gasoline at the bump. It seems to me like this will be a great time to be able to -- I know this is politically unpopular, but I'm not running for office so I can say it, okay? This would be a great time to just put a little bump on to the tax of the tax rate on gasoline and use that money to rebuild the crumbling infrastructure of this country. What an embarrassment. 30, 40, 50 years ago, we were -- our country was known for its infrastructure. The people came here to study how we built bridges. And today, you look at it, overwhelms our bridges, our infrastructure as a whole. Just recently, we received a D+, and they were begging of the fact that it wasn't merely the D+, okay? We don't need infrastructure. With another manufacturing powerhouse in the 21st century, we need infrastructure that gives an A+, not a D+. This is a great opportunity to rebuild our infrastructure. I'm extremely disappointed that we continue to kick the can down the road on funding with 3-month extension after extension after extension. I believe that there's something like 33 or 34, 3-month extensions since 2008. That's an embarrassment. And I really hope that our leaders step up to the plate and do not miss this great opportunity to rebuild the infrastructure in this country.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, clearly, the way that we have been able to grow our automotive presence has been through investments in our company. [indiscernible] the gases for all our sheet mills, the wide-light project at Berkeley, the work that we've done and the advanc
componenttext: Okay. Well, clearly, the way that we have been able to grow our automotive presence has been through investments in our company. [indiscernible] the gases for all our sheet mills, the wide-light project at Berkeley, the work that we've done and the advances that we have made, advance high-strength steels, those have opened the doors for us in growing our automotive presence. And I also have to say that the automotive companies recognizing the long-term sustainability of Nucor and the quality of service that we've been able to provide to them, that's attracted them and given the opportunity to grow in those areas. In terms of your specific question relative to how we see it growing over the next 2 years, the answer to that would be a yes. We're basing that upon qualifications that we've already have been through and have passed and qualified for applications in future platforms and commitments that have been to us on future platforms. So we are confident in that projections of 2 million to 3 million tons. I would also add just one more thing on that. As you've mentioned, commercial and marketing, we recognize the need to improve our marketing into automotive. And to that end, we established sales office right in Detroit. It's the first time Nucor's had a sales office located in Detroit. We have named a sales manager to oversee automotive specifically. And this is an extremely experienced guy with a lot of years in the service. And again, we are confident that we will be able to commit -- will be able to build a commitment that I'm making to you and that our commercial team dis made to me, that we will get to 2 million tons over the next 2 to 3 years.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Great. And then second one on natural gas. I know you guys have stopped drilling kind of there for a couple of years. Could you give us an update on how you're positioned there with wells declining? How are you looking at 2016? Any need or desire to hedge out your gas exposure?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right now, given the pricing that we're seeing a natural gas that we expect to continue through 2016, we don't see any significant change in our drilling program. There might be a couple of wells that we might have to drill in order to maintain the leases
componenttext: Right now, given the pricing that we're seeing a natural gas that we expect to continue through 2016, we don't see any significant change in our drilling program. There might be a couple of wells that we might have to drill in order to maintain the leases on the property, and we would want to do that. We've got some great property then. We want to maintain the leases on those properties. But frankly, I don't see us changing our drilling program at this time. And in terms of hedging, we feel confident that we see natural gas pricing remaining low for at least next year. And so we're pretty comfortable with our gas position.
